subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Non-residential Conveyance Duty

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Can the minister explain the Prime Minister's rationalisation in his letter to the Australian yesterday, in which he said:

question.para: At a minimum, even if all States remove non-residential conveyance duty as soon as they can afford it, Treasury estimates their cumulative gain over the decade to be around $17 billion.

Given that Treasury has been able to arrive at a specific estimate of $17 billion, what assumptions have they made about how long the states will maintain non-residential conveyance dutyâone of the taxes that the states are supposed to be abolishing as part of the GST package? Will this tax be maintained for one, two, three or 10 years?

talk.start.para: âI am very grateful to Senator George Campbell for that question because the Prime Minister did write an important letter to the Australian , which was published, which gives the lie, I think, to some of the comments your colleagues have made in recent days over this issue. It is an important letter. I again thank Senator Campbell for asking me this question. Let me read to the Senate some important aspects which deal with the issues that Senator Campbell raised. The Prime Minister said, among other things:

answer.para: The Intergovernmental Agreement on the Reform of Commonwealth State Financial Relationsâsigned by all State and Territory leadersâspecified removal dates for a range of taxes and stamp duties, except stamp duties on non-residential conveyances of real property.
In relation to stamp duties on non-residential conveyances, the agreement stipulated that while all States agreed to its removalâ
you understand that, that `all states agreed to its removal'â
the tax will cease to apply from a date to be determined.â
by the Ministerial Council. So I am aware of the Prime Minister's letter, and those are the two important paragraphs. He went on to sayâand this deals with the nub of your question:

At a minimum, even if all States remove non-residential conveyance duty as soon as they can afford it, Treasury estimates their cumulative gain over the decade to be around $17 billion. To the extent that the States remove these stamp duties at a later date, the size of the gains will be higher.

talk.start.para: âAt a later date than 10 years?
âI will repeat it, if you missed that point, Senator:

answer.para: To the extent that the States remove these stamp duties at a later date, the size of the gains will be higher.
The letter goes on:

The principal advantage of the Government's tax reform plan is that it provides the States and Territories with access to a secure and growing source of revenueârevenue to be spent on schools, hospitals and police services. This is acknowledged by State and Territory leadersâ

talk.start.para: âAre you going to answer the question at all?
âThat is exactly the question that was asked.
âThat is not the question. You read the letter. He asked you a question about the letter.
âOrder! Senators on my left!
âThank you, Madam President. Again, it is a bit hard. You try to respond in detail to questionsâ

âMadam President, I rise on a point of order. The question was about the letter. The questioner had actually read the letter. Senator Kemp is now reading the letter. The prospect of his ever coming to answer the question appears absolutely remote. Will you direct him to answer the question that was actually put to him and not just fill up question time by needlessly reading information we know about and in fact have based a question on in the case of Senator Campbell?
âThere is no point of order.

âSenator Campbell would not have had to ask the question if he had read the letter carefully. He did not read the letter carefully. What he did was take a question written out by Senator Cook and then he read it blindly into the Senate record. I am answering the question that was asked. It would have been better and would have saved the Senate's time if Senator Campbell had bothered to read the letter rather than read the question that Senator Cook gave to him. The letter continues:

answer.para: All of the revenue from the GST goes to the States and Territories and the gains to them grow over time. Treasury projections based on estimates agreed at the time of the premiers conference indicate that cumulative gains to the States and Territories through to the end of the next decade once all stamp duties have been removed will range from $17 billion to $26 billion.
The exact amount by which the States will benefit will depend on the growth in the economy and the precise timing of the removal of stamp duties.

I thank Senator Campbell for the question. I thank him for the opportunity to bring to the attention of the wider public the important letter that the Prime Minister wrote to the Australian . I think that deals precisely with the question that Senator Campbell asked me. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the minister, through you, Madam President: was the Prime Minister just plain wrong when he told Neil Mitchell last week that the states would not get the GST unless they abolished a non-residential conveyance duty, along with the other nine state taxes?

âAgain, it is a great pity. I read a response to Senator Campbell, he does not bother to listen, and then he gets up and asks a question which was dealt with. The issue that you are concerned with has been dealt with by the Prime Minister's letter. All I can do is urge you to read it, Senator Campbell. Why don't you read the Prime Minister's letter instead of wasting the Senate's time?

âMy question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Customs and the Minister representing the Attorney-General, Senator Vanstone. The Howard government has taken the lead in addressing the national tragedy of domestic violence. Would the minister please inform the Senate about the new report on Model domestic violence laws ?

âI thank Senator Payne for her question. She has had a longstanding interest in these issues for many years prior to coming into parliament, which she has maintained in parliament. Domestic violence is one of the most important issues facing our community. It causes havoc in the lives of many Australians and costs the Australian community in a very human way and therefore is a very high priority for the Howard government. Yesterday I released a report which recommends quite sweeping changes to laws relating to domestic violence. The report was prepared by a working party of Commonwealth, state and territory officials under the Partnerships Against Domestic Violence Project. The report, entitled Model domestic violence laws , is a very important step towards improved and consistent laws in this area.

answer.para: A key recommendation of the report is that the law should provide for immediate registration and portability of domestic violence orders around Australia. The Commonwealth will assist with this by establishing a new national police information system through a $50 million initiative entitled Crimtrack. Without an effective and truly national police information system, we simply cannot give the victims of domestic violence immediate protection no matter where they travel in Australia. Additionally, developing consistent grounds for obtaining orders is also a key recommendation of the report. The report proposes that an order may be made where a person reasonably fears that an act of domestic violence will be committed or where a person has committed an act of domestic violence against another and is likely to do so again unless restrained.

Currently, the grounds vary from state to state. In some states the basis for obtaining an order is reasonable fear that domestic violence will be committed; in other states the test is based on an actual act of domestic violence. Again, there are recommendations for improved emergency procedures. The report recommends that police officers in all states and territories should be able to apply for telephone orders in situations where urgent protection is required outside working hours. The report recommends that police officers in all states and territories should be able to temporarily restrain potentially violent offenders at the scene of domestic violence incidents without the need for an arrest. We think that this is vital in helping to prevent violence against women and children, but it is not yet available in all states and territories.

Children require more protection. The proposed laws recognise that children are often caught up in not only the process of domestic violence but also the associated court procedures. Special measures are proposed for the protection of the privacy of children. The model laws allow for the clos ure of a court where a domestic violence proceeding involves a child.

This is a final report on the basis of a discussion paper that was released in 1997 by the Prime Minister. There has been a round of consultations and now we have the final report. Obviously there will be further comments on this report and they will of course be made available to all ministers concerned. The report complements other initiatives under the federal government's $100 million Partnerships Against Domestic Violence Project such as rural and remote domestic violence initiatives, the relationship support service for men and the domestic violence community education package for young people.

Next month I will host a national forum focusing on the perpetrators of domestic violence. The Senate can be assured that the federal government is committed to preventing domestic violence and ensuring that perpetrators of domestic violence understand that their actions will simply not be tolerated.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Poverty Traps

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. I presume the minister is aware that the Business Council is hosting a seminar today on the importance of reducing poverty traps if we want to reduce unemployment. I ask: does the minister support the need to remove more poverty traps? Does the minister agree with evidence from economists Chris Murphy, Geoff Carmody and Michael Keating to the Senate tax inquiry that reducing poverty traps is one of the main devices by which the tax package will generate jobs?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âPoverty traps are always a problem area. Quite clearly, it is important to ensure that there are as few disincentives as possible built into the system of welfare or any other transfer payments. Clearly, the government believes that it is an important issue, but that in no shape or form reflects on the tax package that has been put before the Australian parliament. That is all about providing massive incentives for people to not only have a greater spending capacity but also be able to be taxed on their consumption. That is, I think, a very important aspect of poverty traps. You get the incentives in the right place, you encourage people to save, you give them significant taxation reductions and you put them in a much better net position. That is the overall intention of the package. It is clearly designed to ensure that lower income Australians in particular are much better off as a result.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, if you are concerned about property traps then why haven't you removed the biggest one of all, and that is the one faced by the unemployed? If they want to accept part-time work, they lose with that poverty trap 90 cents in every dollar that they earn. Are you aware of the criticism from Dr Keating, one of the five economists whose plan is being debated by the Business Council today, on this very pointâthat the government has failed to address the worst of the poverty traps? In your answer you talked about the massive incentives within the tax package; I presume you are talking about the $6.8 billion of tax cuts to high income earners. Why is it that you have managed to find the $6.8 billion for high income earners but not the $500 million that it will cost to remove this disincentive for those who are unemployed to accept part-time work?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âIt is my understanding that the effect of marginal tax rates for low income families will be reduced from something in the order of 80 per cent down to around 60 per cent, so that is a very significant move forward. There are unemployed people who are low income earners or who are members of low income families so it obviously makes a very significant difference to them if that is the case. I do not have the figures in front of me, but as I recall, depending on the deciles used, it is easy to demonstrate that overall this package is not one that favours high income earners.
âOh yeah? Ask the high rollers.

âOr high rollers, or the punch drunk. The tax package is designed to provide incentives at all levels and it does that. It certainly contains personal income taxes and family benefits which are a very significant part of the overall package and which will provide incentives for people and ensure that they are able to take up employment opportunities where they arise.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Local Government

talk.start.para: âMy question without notice is directed to the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, Senator Macdonald. I ask why the minister made the claim in a letter which he had published in the Jimboomba Times in his own home state on 14 April that:

question.para: A leading council organisation in its submission to the Senate inquiry indicated that between 90 and 95 per cent of services provided by councils would not attract a GST.

Is the minister aware that the submission to which he referred from the Municipal Association of Victoria actually said that 90 to 95 per cent of local government income would be GST free, not services as the minister claimed? Is the minister aware that the MAV calculated that there would be `217 fees across a range of services, of which about 117 will have a GST applied to them'?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Mackay for allowing me to emphasise again that by far the greatest impact on local government is that it will be GST freeâno impact of the GST at all. para.inline: The answer read as followsâ

speech.para: Senator Amanda Vanstoneâon 22 April 1999 (Hansard Page 3586) Senator Woodley asked the following question of the Special Minister of State, Senator Ellison:

Is it true that the Commonwealth government is pressuring the Queensland government to accept some 250 amendments to its native title state regime legislation? What is the nature of the amendments which are being proposed? Is it true that the effect of these amendments will be to wind back the rights of indigenous people which have been achieved by the Queensland government in their recently passed legislation? Is this an attempt by the Commonwealth government to ensure that the inadequacy of the Commonwealth's Native Title Amendment Act is repeated in Queensland?
The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
No. The Commonwealth government is not pressuring the Queensland government to accept amendments to its native title state regime legislation.

The Native Title Act 1993 (NTA) as amended by the Native Title Amendment Act 1998 allows State and Territory governments to introduce their own alternative regimes to operate instead of the NTA right to negotiate provisions. This is designed to allow States and Territories to integrate native title procedures into their own land management systems provided the Commonwealth is satisfied that the criteria set out in the NTA are met. The determinations necessary to allow the State or Territory provisions to apply instead of the NTA are disallowable instruments.

A number of jurisdictions are working towards establishing such alternative native title procedures and some have introduced or passed relevant legislation. As would be expected following the recent comprehensive reform of the NTA, officials from my Department have had discussions with a number of jurisdictions in relation to the NTA criteria that must be met.

Following extensive discussions with Queensland officials, I am advised that they are considering a number of amendments to their native title provisions. However, Queensland officials have informed my Department that these amendments do not represent a change in policy; they relate to workability, compliance and technical drafting issues only.

talk.start.para: âOn 28 April, Madam President, in my capacity representing the Minister for Immi gration and Multicultural Affairs, Senator Margetts asked two questions of me and I seek leave to incorporate into Hansard answers provided by the minister.

speech.para: Leave granted.

para.inline: The answer read as followsâ

speech.para: On 28 April in my capacity representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs I was asked by Senator Margetts the following questions:

. "My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Senator Vanstone. Can the minister tell me: given the deteriorating human rights situation in East Timor and given the government's current policy of not accepting people fleeing from East Timor as eligible for refugee status in Australia, what intention does the government have in relation to East Timorese people arriving at Australia's borders seeking refugee status in this country?"

. "Can the minister guarantee that east Timorese fleeing the territory will not automatically be detained or deported on arrival in Australia if they have inappropriate documentation? What plans does the Australian government have to facilitate the processing of visa applications in East Timor for those seeking protection in Australia, given the need for an expedited process? I realise that, similar to your first answer, a portion of that question at least will be on notice."

para.inline: Answer

speech.para: There is no blanket policy under which East Timorese are ineligible for refugee status in Australia. Each application for protection is considered on its own merits. Under the Migration Act any person who arrives in Australia without an appropriate authority to enter must be refused immigration clearance and must be removed as soon as practicable unless they have made an application for a visa.

All unauthorised arrivals are carefully interviewed to ascertain the reasons for their travel to this country. Where they raise claims or give information which prima facie may engage Australia's protection obligations, they are not removed but are instead assisted to apply for protection in Australia.

The Migration Act requires that all unauthorised arrivals must be held in detention pending the finalisation of any visa application and, if they are unsuccessful in their application, their removal. The Act provides mechanisms for release on a case by case basis where, for example, the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has not made a decision on their visa application within 6 months, or in the case of children, people over 75 years of age or who have special health requirements that cannot be appropriately met in detention

The situation in East Timor is very fluid and the Australian Government, and the Prime Minister in particular, have been involved in a range of important negotiations with the Indonesian government on the future of East Timor. In relation to people in East Timor applying for visas to come to Australia, our embassy in Jakarta will continue to process visa applications to Australia according to the requirements of the visa class applied for.

âI move:

Senator Kemp has left the chamber and it is no surprise. He has today misled the Australian people outrageously. talk.start.para: âIt is an interesting argument that Senator Conroy has given us. He has given us the argument that when a business offers a rebate it should be required to pay GST, notwithstanding the fact that there is a rebate. If you are, for example, running a business and you give a discount to somebody, it would be absurd to expect that you could not claim that the discount you gave should be calculated when you work out the value added. The goods and services tax is a tax on the value added component. You look at your sales less your cost of sales. That is the basis of a goods and services tax. So if you have a rebate that you give, then of course you should be able to deduct the rebate for the purposes of calculating the tax liability. That is something that Senator Conroy does not understand, but that is exactly what we are doing here.
âWhy didn't you put it in the bill?
âIt was always the case that the legislation was going to provide that the goods and services tax should be applied to the margin.
âWhy isn't it in the bill?
âIf there is any doubt about this, I suggest that honourable senators on the other side of the chamber should in fact look at the government's policy document dated August 1998. It says:

speech.para: The GST will apply to the operator's margin, not to the prizes paid out. That is, the tax will apply to the difference between total ticket sales or bets taken and the value of prizes or winnings already paid out. As states already tax gambling highly, then there may need to be corresponding reductions in state gambling taxes.

They do not want to understand what we are talking about in terms of rebates, or maybe they cannot understand it. Let me explain it to them in terms that they can understand. There is one rebate that they know about all too well on the other side, and that is the rebate given by the Commonwealth Bank of Australia to the former Prime Minister on his borrowings. What was the rebate the Commonwealth Bank gave to Paul Keating on his borrowings? It was $4.9 million of write-off, in May 1995. He did not have to pay $4.9 million of interest. That is a rebate. Maybe that is a rebate they might understand on the other side of the chamber. We understand it on this side of the chamber.

talk.start.para: âWould you call him a high roller?

âHe was a high roller for sure. He just rolled right over the top of that interest bill. He did not have to pay it. I suppose there is a difference between the Commonwealth Bank and casinos. When you go into a casino, you do not know whether you are going to win or lose. There is no sure thing in a casino. But as far as Paul Keating was concerned the Commonwealth Bank was a sure thing. He was sure he was not going to have to pay interest. He was sure he was going to be able to take the money and run. Everybody else, when they go into a casino, is gambling. Paul Keating goes in and just makes withdrawal after withdrawal after withdrawal and he never has to pay it back. A rebate is basically a discount that you give and you should not have to pay GST on it. So the Commonwealth Bank, for example, should not be expected to pay GST on rebates it gives to Paul Keating any more than a casino should be expected to pay GST on rebates it gives to regular customers.

speech.para: It reminds me of the old song My God, How the Money Rolls In. talk.start.para: âAs is Labor's wont when they don't have any policy issues to put before us, when they have nothing of substance, they get into the game of slinging mud. It is described as `the only game in town'; it is the biggest game in town. For the Victorian government, that has been demonstrated to be a fact over and over again. We are now seeing, with an election coming up in Victoria, these attitudes being reflected by Liberals in the federal government as well.

Over a month ago, on 13 March, the Prime Minister and the entire Liberal Party hierarchy were among the 300 guests who were gathered at Mr Kroger's and Miss Ann Peacock's wedding, which was held in the Palladium Room in the Crown Casino in Melbourne. They all appeared to enjoy themselves immensely. I have no doubt that Miss Ann Peacock was very familiar with the place; she was in fact a public relations officer for Crown Casino. At this society wedding there was immense enjoyment, as one could understand, because the Liberal Party personnel obviously were of the view that they were amongst friends. They were enjoying the `most favoured status' treatment received from Victoria Inc. that we have noticed again and again.

I think we should also know exactly who was in attendance. We know that Ron Walker was there. We know that Lloyd Williams definitely had a ball. We know that the new ownerâKerry Packerâwas not there, but we do know that his son Jamie was there. We know that Mr Costello was there. We know that Mr John Howard was there. Poor old Jeff Kennett and his good wife, Felicity, due to the bad publicity associated with the loss of their defamation case the day before, withdrew their attendance.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The document read as followsâ

para.inline: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE SENATE COMMUNITY AFFAIRS REFERENCES COMMITTEE INQUIRY INTO PUBLIC DENTAL SERVICES

speech.para: FEBRUARY 1999

para.inline: Introduction

speech.para: 1. On 28 May 1998, the Senate Community Affairs References Committee Inquiry into Public Dental Services released its report. The terms of reference for the inquiry covered:
. current and future dental needs of low income earners;
. the effect of the abolition of the Commonwealth Dental Health Program (CDHP);
. the nature of the Commonwealth's responsibility under the Australian Constitution to make laws for the provision of dental services;
. the Commonwealth's role in setting and monitoring national goals for oral health in Australia; and
. options for reforming the delivery of public dental services.

2. The Committee made nine recommendations, some of which suggested some future Commonwealth involvement in aspects of public dental care, particularly through the Public Health Partnerships. Significantly, however, the Committee did not recommend the reintroduction of the Commonwealth Dental Health Program (CDHP) or some similar large scale funding intervention. The Coalition members of the Committee noted in their minority report that the recommendations appeared to be "an expensive and ineffective method of tackling a problem which has traditionally been the responsibility of the States". They were also reluctant for the Commonwealth "to issue directives to the States, which should be free to deliver services in the manner they see fit".

3. Notwithstanding the Committee's finding that some low income earners currently have difficulty accessing public dental services, the Government's position continues to be that the provision of public dental services is a State responsibility and that the States must resolve the structural, management and financial problems in their dental services. Unfortunately, the advantages gained by the CDHP in reducing waiting times and improving access were largely offset by the unwillingness of the States to use the time to enhance their public dental services, despite knowing that there was no guarantee that the CDHP would be extended. To its credit, Queensland accepted its responsibility when the CDHP was wound up and provided additional funding to maintain services. The fact that the access problems in some States are not evident in Queensland shows the problems are not as intractable as suggested in the report. Nor, by implication, is it necessary for the Commonwealth to intervene yet again in what is essentially a State matter. The Government also notes that the Committee concluded that while the Commonwealth has the constitutional power to provide or regulate dental services it can exercise that power at its own discretion.

4. With the introduction of the GST, States will be better off than they would be under existing Commonwealth/State financial arrangements. The additional revenue that will accrue to the States through the GST will be at the disposal of the States to augment the range of health services available to the public, including public dental services. It is the Government's intention to allow States to determine their own priorities in the level of public dental services they provide within their jurisdictions, as they traditionally have done.

5. The Government's overall response to the recommendations of the report is that by and large, Commonwealth involvement in their implementation would be ineffective. The States must take up those recommendations they consider will improve access and service delivery. For its part the Commonwealth is prepared to assist the States to deliver better services by facilitating the inclusion of reliable oral health data in the National Public Health Information Development Plan, if this is what the States want.
6. The Government provides the following specific responses to the recommendations presented in the Senate Committee's report.

para.inline: Recommendation 1: That the Commonwealth, in consultation with the States and Territories and other key stakeholders in the public and private dental sectors, support the development of programs to improve the promotion of oral health throughout Australia.

speech.para: 7. Under the National Public Health Partnership Memorandum of Understanding, to which all Australian Health Ministers are signatories, State and Territories are responsible for the provision of health promotion services to meet the needs of their respective populations. If a jurisdiction determines that oral health promotion is a high priority, it is able to develop specific programs within the context of the full range of health promotion services offered within the State. Oral health has not been established by Australian Health Ministers as a National Health Priority Area, which is the precursor to planning for coordinated national action to achieve agreed national targets and performance measures.

para.inline: Recommendation 2: That the Commonwealth Government support the introduction of a vocational training program for new dental graduates, especially to assist in the delivery of oral health services to people in rural or remote areas.

speech.para: 8. The Government supports the implementation of a vocational training program and notes that given each State's responsibility to maintain an adequate workforce in the public health sector, it is a State responsibility to cover the cost of establishing or maintaining such a program.

9. At the same time, the Commonwealth does provide some support for essential infrastructure in the form of multi-purpose service centres that are available to underpin the provision of oral health services to people in rural and remote areas, should States decide to invest in these services as a priority. Also Government's University Department of Rural Health Program has the potential to assist in the delivery of oral health services to people in rural and remote areas. The establishment of a university department at Whyalla in South Australia provides an example of where the Government's 1996 initiative has established appropriate infrastructure in the nearby city of Port Augusta for a viable dental service. With the cooperation of the university sector, the model established at Port Augusta could be introduced in other rural areas of Australia where there are university departments of rural health: that is, Broken Hill, Mount Isa, Shepparton, Launceston, Geraldton and Alice Springs.

10. Some Aboriginal Medical Services have infrastructure in place which can be used to support dental graduates undertaking vocational training supported by the States. The use of facilities in these services by dental graduates undertaking training will not only provide excellent learning opportunities but will benefit the communities by providing a minimum level of service. Appropriate supervision arrangements for dental graduates would need to be a key element of the vocational training provided in these areas.

11. The Government notes from the Senate report that a working party with primary interests in the operation of a vocational training program for dental graduates is examining this matter and that the States and Territories will consider the report of the working party when it becomes available. The Senate report does, however, point to the difficulties of the proposal such as supervision of trainees in remote areas and the estimated cost; issues that will need to be considered by any authority adopting the proposal.

para.inline: Recommendation 3: That the use of dental auxiliaries such as therapists and hygienists be expanded, particularly to cater for the needs of specific disadvantaged groups and that, to this end, the States and Territories be encouraged to review legislation restricting the employment of such auxiliaries.

speech.para: 12. The Government supports this recommendation. As State legislation limits the employment of dental therapists to the public sector and its provider agencies, the report has highlighted a need to examine and amend relevant State legislation, both in regard to where therapists can be employed and the age limitations of the client population they can treat.

13. The specific dental workforce requirements for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders in the community sector will need to be addressed in any legislative changes made by the State/ Territories. These needs can be identified within the context of the Framework agreements for indigenous health between the Commonwealth, the State/Territories and the community sector where regional planning processes are being established. A National Health Workforce Modelling Project underway will also be assessing overall workforce requirements in this area.
14. This recommendation appears to have the support of the key players in the provision of dental services and now requires adoption by States and Territories.

para.inline: Recommendation 4: That support be given to a national oral health training strategy for health workers and carers, specifically including those working in the fields of aged care and Aboriginal health.

speech.para: 13. The intention of the above recommendation in promoting nationally consistent oral health training is supported. Should the States choose to develop national strategies through a forum such as the Australian Health Ministers' Advisory Council, the Commonwealth would be supportive.

14. The Government recognises the special needs of older people with regard to dental health. The Standards and Guidelines for Residential Aged Care Services state that residents' oral and dental health should be maintained though ensuring that regular assessment, treatment and access to appropriate dental services occurs. Workers in the residential aged care sector have a responsibility to understand that oral health has a major influence on residents' quality of life. The guidelines suggest that staff education should address oral and dental care, including strategies for residents with dementia and challenging behaviour. While the Government encourages the pursuit of best practice in all facets of residential aged care, by both service providers and professional associations, it prefers not to be prescriptive in its approach as to how this can be achieved. However, oral health training strategies could be incorporated into existing education programs for carers of the aged, or where necessary, programs could be implemented.

15. It is important to consider oral health training, particularly training in prevention, in the context of the overall health needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. Programs in oral health can be introduced into health worker training as part of the overall primary health care approach. A review of health worker training is currently underway and will be considering a range of issues including gaps in training delivery. Oral health care training can be taken into account as part of the review process.

para.inline: Recommendation 5: That the Commonwealth Government assist the States and Territories to establish, conduct and evaluate highly targeted pilot programs to address the priority oral health needs of the following specific disadvantaged groups: pre school-age children (1 to 5 years), young adult Health Card holders (18 to 25 years), aged adult Health Card holders (65+ years), the home bound, rural and remote communities, and indigenous Australians. Such programs should include a capacity for the individual beneficiary to make a contribution to the treatment costs.

speech.para: 16. The evaluation of highly targeted pilot programs to address priority oral health needs is highly desirable if the needs of specific disadvantaged groups are to be addressed. Under the former CDHP the Commonwealth funded several demonstration projects with the aim of evaluating strategies for improving service delivery in rural and remote areas, including services for indigenous people. The evaluations provided some useful models of service delivery which States have incorporated into their public dental health care programs. At this stage it is up to the States to pilot programs for any other disadvantaged groups within their jurisdictions that they consider require special attention.

para.inline: Recommendation 6: That the Commonwealth Government adopt a leadership role in introducing a national oral health policy, and give consideration to the possibility of using the National Public Health Partnership as the vehicle for developing and implementing that policy in partnership with the States and Territories.

speech.para: 17. The National Public Health Partnership is a working arrangement between the Commonwealth and the States and Territories to strengthen the national public health infrastructure and response capacity. Its focus is on public health; that is, disease and injury prevention and control, and health promotion. It does not have a mandate in policies and programs for the treatment, management and care of diseases and illnesses once they have occurred. Recommendations 6 and 7 clearly envisage a national oral health policy, which has a "whole of system" approach; that is, there is an emphasis on access to treatment services, quality and service targets in addition to prevention and promotion. Nevertheless, the National Public Health Partnership, in considering national public health information requirements, is including information about oral health status and service utilisation in its deliberations. This work should, in the longer term, enhance population health outcomes in the States and Territories.

18. In addition, the Commonwealth funds the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare to support the Dental Statistics and Research Unit to collect and analyse data and report on adult access to dental care and adult oral care.

para.inline: Recommendation 7: That the national oral health policy include the:
. Setting of national oral health goals;
. establishment of national standards for the provision of, and access to, oral health care and the quality of services;

speech.para: . establishment of national strategies and priorities for oral health care reform, with an emphasis on preventive dentistry;

para.inline: . setting of minimum service targets; and
. monitoring national oral health goals through the maintenance of a national data collection and evaluation centre and undertaking research into current and projected needs.

speech.para: 19. This recommendation is partially supported by the Government, in so far as the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare (funded by the Health portfolio) will continue to maintain its data collection, including dental statistics, for the foreseeable future. This data will provide basic information for States' use in planning, policy formulation and evaluation.

20. At present the Commonwealth is unaware of any evidence for declaring oral health a National Health Priority Area, which would be the necessary first step for national policy development, encompassing a "whole of health system" approach, the negotiation of goals and targets, service benchmarks, national monitoring and reporting processes.

21. Nevertheless, the Commonwealth will table recommendations six and seven in the National Public Health Partnership forum to ensure adequate consideration of their public health aspects. Those aspects of the recommendations that relate to treatment as opposed to prevention and promotional activities would need to be separately considered by States and Territories as they are outside the domain of public health and are not the business of the National Public Health Partnership.

para.inline: Recommendation 8: That the Commonwealth allocate resources for a national oral health survey, to be conducted as a priority, to establish data on the oral health status and oral health needs of the Australian community.

speech.para: 22. The Commonwealth supports the collection of data on the oral health status and oral health needs of the Australian community. To this end the Commonwealth funds the Dental Statistics Research Unit of the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare.

23. Good baseline data on oral health is important and the Commonwealth is actively trying to include the collection of such information in the National Public Health Information Development Plan now being finalised as part of the work of the National Public Health Information Working Group.

para.inline: Recommendation 9: That the Commonwealth Department of Health and Family Services create a dedicated section or appoint an appropriately qualified senior officer with responsibility for oral health matters, and that the necessary resources to fulfil the role and responsibilities of such an office be provided.

speech.para: 24. This recommendation is not supported by the Government. The level of Commonwealth involvement in dental health is appropriate given that the planning, funding and delivery of public dental services are State responsibilities. Policy matters across States are properly raised in the Health Ministers' forum. The National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) convenes specialist working parties when necessary to consider specific dental issues such as fluoridation of water supplies and amalgam and mercury use in dentistry. Appropriate members of the dental profession are then appointed as necessary.

talk.start.para: âMadam Deputy President, I seek leave to make a statement in relation to a question asked of me by Senator Schacht at question time.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âDuring question time today, Senator Schacht asked me whether I had instructed ATSIC to remove from the ATSIC web site an assessment of the effects of the GST package on indigenous communities. I answered that I had not. I wish to reaffirm that I have not instructed ATSIC to remove any assessment of the effects of the GST package on indigenous communities from their web site over the term of this parliament. Naturally, I assumed that Senator Schacht's question related to this parliament and the current debate.

speech.para: However, during the course of the campaign prior to the last election, ATSIC had on their web site an assessment of the effects of the GST package on indigenous communities. I considered that material to be highly political and, therefore, in breach of the guidelines relating to material that departments can have on their web sites during the caretaker period. The guidelines make it clear that material of a political nature must not be placed on departmental or ministerial web sites during a campaign. Naturally, I asked ATSIC to remove the material, as I considered it to be in breach of the caretaker guidelines.

talk.start.para: âOn behalf of Senator Carr, I move:

speech.para: That the Senate notes the inconsistency in the view of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) that it would be inappropriate for a non-Australian to open the Olympic Games, yet appropriate for a non-Australian to remain as Head of State.
In moving this motion, I draw reference to the double standards that the Prime Minister of Australia has applied to our mostâ

talk.start.para: âPlease do not reflect upon the Prime Minister.

âprestigious sporting event. The Sydney Olympics is a good news story for Australia and, indeed, it is a very good news story for the government. It is an opportunity for Australia to be at the forefront of international attention. For Sydney, the exposure and attention derived from being an Olympic host city is immeasurable.

speech.para: That quite memorable 4.00 a.m. radio broadcast in which Juan Antonio Samaranch announced that Sydney had been chosen as Olympic host city will forever stick in my mind, and we have heard much over recent times since then. However, in the euphoria surrounding that announcement and the profound level of work that has occurred since, both within the organising committee and within sporting organisations in this country, it seems that one issue has yet remained unresolved: who will have the great honour of opening the Olympic Games.

One would think this would be quite a simple question, that indeed we would turn to the person who heads the Australian government. But we find ourselves in the intervening period embroiled in a debate about whether or not Australia should become a republic. The person who one would think is the obvious choice, having in his hands the prime ministership of this country, we now find advocating in the republican debate that Australia should not have an Australian head of state; that, indeed, it is entirely appropriate to have someone elseâthat is, Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth IIâfulfilling that role.

I had the privilege of attending the Constitutional Convention as a delegate on behalf of the Australian parliament, indeed the Australian Labor Party. There I heard the Prime Minister advocate at great length his commitment to an Australia that persisted with a monarchy and a monarchist in the position of head of state. So it is with some surprise that we come to this point in this particular debate where we find the Prime Minister very pleased to announce to all Australians and, indeed, our monarchy overseas that he will be the one opening the Olympic Games.

Sitting back and looking at how this scenario plays out, I often wonder about the conversations that could have occurred within the Prime Minister's office: `Well, we've got this position on the monarchy; we want to perpetuate Australia as a monarchist state with Queen Elizabeth II as our head of state. But oh, oh, that means we might miss out on a good news story; we might miss out on opening the Olympic Games. So let's just put aside our commitment to Queen Elizabeth being our head of state, and why don't you open the games, Prime Minister?' `What a great idea.'

So here we have it. We find ourselves in this place contemplating the double standard that has been applied to this whole issue of whether or not Australia should become a republic. With the acute symbolism relating to our status as a nation provided by the opportunity of the Olympics on the global stage, in my view we should proceed down the path to becoming the Republic of Australia before the Olympic Games. Why? So that we can have an Australian head of state, the official head of state, being the one to preside over and conduct the opening of that prestigious event.

It is a pretty sad reflection on a government whose approach to governance to date, I think, has been riddled with many inconsistencies, and I would focus particularly on its inconsistencies in relation to sport. It is clear that this government is happy to involve itself in every good news story in relation to sport. But it is not so keen on putting its money where its mouth is. It is not so keen on coming up with the dollars that will fund Australia's capability to develop its presence in community sport and that will ensure that we can hang on to what is a very proud tradition and record in our performance and participation levels in what is far more than a weekend or weeknight pastime. Indeed, sport is part of our culture, and an essential part at that. I look over the past three years, as I see John Howard announce to the country that he will open this great eventâ

talk.start.para: âMr Howard, please.

âwith, no doubt, great fanfare and international coverage, and note that this government has withdrawn funding from sport, particularly at the community level, in the lead-up to the Olympic Games. At each successive budget we have seen a further diminution in public investment in community sport in this country. Whilst there has been an attempt to maintain the elite funding levels in preparation for the Olympics, that has been at the expense of community based sport.

speech.para: So, in the very first instance, this government is prepared to leap to the highest podium, the highest platform, and claim credit for a glorious event in the most blatant way possible, but it is not prepared to underpin that involvement or that commitment at the elite level where it countsâat the grassroots level, providing an opportunity for all Australians to participate in sport.

Over the last three years of the coalition government, we have seen a complete rejection of the structure that Labor put in place in its previous period of governance. Labor put in place a comprehensive approach to not just managing the community level of activity and participation in sport but also building a structure that allowed the progression of community athletes into elite sport. More and more we have seen under the coalition government this disaggregation between community sport and elite sport. Why? Because they are just not prepared to supply that base level funding to the sporting associations.

So, when I talk about the government withdrawing their commitment to sport, it is actually at that fundamental level of how communities organise themselves around participation. A significant number of national sporting associations were actually defunded in the first budget of the coalition government. Surprise, surprise, they were the borderline sports: is it recreation or is it sport? Recfish is a classic example of this. It is one of the greatest participation sports in this country. Yet, through an elaborate interpretation of what constituted a sport, the govern ment decided that they would defund this particular organisation, regardless of the fact that fishing and the sport associated with it has one of the highest participation rates in this country, and for many of the participants it is the only sport they participate in.

The issue of participatory sport goes one step furtherâthat is, where its status is in the policy scheme of things. The coalition government have reduced funding in this area and they have done it at a time when the short-sightedness of this policy could not be more obvious. They have done it at a time when the Olympic Games actually presents the most profound opportunity to encourage all Australians to participate even further in this particular activity. We do have a great legacy with respect to sport, and why not create an even better one? How often does a country get the Olympic Games?

How often would a country like Australia have the opportunity to actually focus on a level of physical activity, be it centred on organised sport, on the platform of celebrating our national performance in such an international sporting event as the Olympics provides? It does not come along very often, and yet we see this opportunity being squandered as community sport is devalued by this government through defunding and we see the disaggregation of the relationship between elite sporting programs and community level sport.

The other area that is worth mentioning is the Paralympics. So often in the Olympics debate the athletes with disabilities and their event, the Paralympics, do not rate a mention. At this stage, the Paralympic Games are yet to attract a host broadcaster, and a far greater degree of attention needs to be paid to this aspect of the Paralympics event by this government. I ask this question: if the Prime Minister is so keen to involve himself in opening the Olympics, does he have an equal interest in the Paralympics?

The funding pressure on the Paralympic movement and organisation leaves a lot to be desired. This is not an organisation which has access to the sorts of sponsorship arrangements and deals that the able-bodied athletics associations have been able to organise for themselves. They are worthy recipients of very active government support but, unfortunately, that has not been forthcoming. So I put out a challenge to the government in this respect: with all of the hoo-ha, the accolades, the recognition and the good news stories that will come from devoting time, energy, resources and moneyâtaxpayers' money at thatâto what I hope will be an exciting and positive event, why not look a little further to the Paralympic event and look at the inspiration, bravery and courage of those athletes, what they bring to Australian society and how they contribute to the spirit of Australian sporting culture?

Like so many other Australians, I find that the Paralympians, perhaps even more so than the able-bodied athletes, really say what has to be said about the spirit of Australian participatory sport, about having a go and about getting out there and being the best that you can be in, let us face it, very challenging circumstances. For my part, nothing is more inspiring than seeing our athletes with disabilities getting out on the track, getting in the pool or wherever, doing their stuff and bringing home those accolades for Australia.

So where do we go from here? In introducing this issue, I spoke about the Prime Minister's commitment to retaining Australia as a monarchy and about Australia having a sporting culture that goes way beyond just a weekend pastime and the interrelationship between the two. This country really needs a Prime Minister who brings consistency to policy making. We in this country really need a Prime Minister who, if he is to accurately reflect the views as to where we need to go as a nation in developing our identity and in making the most of what is an incredible opportunity in hosting the Olympic Games in this country, first of all, must recognise the importance of an Australian head of state, which he has inadvertently supported by his haste and his endeavour to be at the forefront of this Olympic event.

This inconsistency in the Prime Minister's position is not going unnoticed in the community. It is not going unnoticed that, in the first instance, the Prime Minister argues against an Australian head of state, yet then vehemently advocates behind the scenes that he, as an Australian, must open the Olympic Games because that is what is important. He knew the rules and protocols with respect to the Olympic Games; he knew that it was the job of the Australian head of state to open the Olympic Games. But no, he chose to do a little bit of work behind the scenes and get his face, his body, up on the podium and behind the microphone on the big day in the year 2000.

I do not think the Australian public will forget the Prime Minister's actions when it comes to the referendum that will be conducted later this year in this country to decide whether or not we should go down the path of becoming a republic and put into our Constitution, our laws, that we have an Australian head of state. I actually think the Prime Minister and those in the government who do not support an Australian head of stateâand, hence, the current proposal relating to our progression towards a republicâare politically obligated now to reconsider their position. If they do not reconsider and if the Prime Minister does not turn around now and say to the Australian public, `I was wrong. I now understand the symbolic importance of having an Australian head of state so we can do things like open the Olympic Games,' then I think the Australian public will treat the Prime Minister with the contempt he deserves.

talk.start.para: âSenator Lundy has raised two issues and I will deal with them seriatim. The first is this government's commitment to sport. I do not want to take anything away from Senator Lundy. She is a very good rower, an extremely good rower.
âWhat has that got to do with it? Stick to the issues.

âI am saying that as a compliment, Senator Lundy. I have enjoyed rowing in a boat with her. She is an extremely good rower, but it is not correct for her then to go on and say that this government lacks a commitment to sport; nor is it correct for Senator Lundy to make the extreme observation that somehow we lack a commitment to the Paralympics, not that there was any evidence to support the assertion but, of course, that was not necessary for the purposes of the debate. This is a debate, and we are talking about debating points on the other side.

speech.para: Let us talk about commitment to sport. Everybody knows that the New South Wales government would be in a real bind were it not for the willingness of this government to step in and plug much of the financial shortfall which is facing the Sydney Olympics. On the Labor Party side at a federal level, the belief is that there should be a blank cheque made payable to the Olympics. The reason they believe there should be a blank cheque made payable to the Olympics is that they do not want anything to rebound on the state Labor government in New South Wales.

That is a perfectly valid political position to take. But it is not a valid governmental position to say that there should be a blank cheque to cover any budgetary shortfalls suffered by the Olympics. The fact is that this government has been extremely generous with the New South Wales Olympics. It has been extremely generous both in cash and in kind contributions to making sure that the Olympics is successful.

The federal government, neither when my colleagues on the other side of the chamber occupied the treasury bench nor now, has never been the guarantor of the Olympics. Underlying all of the arguments that you have heard from Senator Lundy is the assumptionâit is a quiet assumption, but it is still there and was running all the way through her speechâthat the federal government should be the guarantor of the Olympics and, more importantly, that it should be the guarantor of the political fortunes of the New South Wales Labor government. That is what they are really asking us to do: to be the guarantor of the fortunes of the New South Wales Labor government. This government has no intention of bailing out the Labor Party's mismanagement in New South Wales.

talk.start.para: âHear, hear! A good point.

âSenator Ellison, a minister of the Crown, has interjected that that is a very good point. It is a good point because he, unlike some of the people on the other side of the chamber, understands that we have an obligation to all of the taxpayers of Australia; our obligation is to the people of Australia as a whole and not to some factional coalition in New South Wales. That is just good government, but it is good government that irks the New South Wales Labor Party and irks their Labor colleagues in Canberra because blood is thicker than water, and it is certainly thicker than money when it comes to the Labor Party. I do not think it is correct for Senator Lundy to make some of the accusations she has made.

speech.para: In relation to the Paralympics, she is totally wrong to suggest that this government is not committed to Paralympic sport. Senator Lundy has done a good job of talking about Paralympics, but she has not had any real involvement with Paralympics. She has not had any real involvement with Paralympic sport. Quite frankly, you get to the point where you wonder why these constant bleatings have to come over and over and over again, and it is just a simple matterâ

talk.start.para: âMr Acting Deputy President, I have a point of order.
âHere we are going to have another spurious point of order because there is going to be no point of order.
âOrder! Senator O'Chee!
âMr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: I believe I have been misrepresented in the Senate.
âYou cannot do it now; do it later.
âYou can't do it now.

âOrder! Senators on my right will come to order. It happens that I am in the chair and I will make the decision on the basis of either the advice of the Clerk or what I know the standing orders to be. In this case, I have to say there is no point of order. Senator Lundy, you have a right under the standing orders to make a personal explanation if you feel you have been misrepresented. I call Senator O'Chee.

âA very good ruling too, Mr Acting Deputy President. I am sorry that I jumped the gun. You had it perfectly under control. Senator Lundy, however, did not have it under control because, yet again, she came forward and made all sorts of spurious allegations about this government's commitment to the Paralympics.
âYou're wrong about my having no involvement, because I have had a long history of involvement. You are talking off the cuffâunresearched.
âNow she wants to scream and yell and rant and rave across the chamber. She had her chance to have her say and she was heard in absolute silence.
âIt is also in the standing orders to direct your remarks through the chair.

âAs I say, Mr Acting Deputy President, she was heard in absolute silence. Now she needs to carry on, yelling and screaming across the chamber. The point is this: this government is committed to ensuring that every athlete gets an opportunity to achieve his or her full potential. One only has to look at the government's gold medal disability program to see the commitment this government made to ensuring that there is money there to raise the issue of disabilities generally and how they affect people in sport. That was an initiative of this coalition government. That gold medal disability access program was not something the Labor Party had. They never had a program like that. It was a program which was put together by the former minister, Warwick Smith, and a very good program.
âSo good he lost his seat.

âSenator Schacht sees everything in terms of crude politics and whether Mr Smith won his seat or did not win his seat. It had nothing to do with the electoral outcome in Bass. But this is an interesting point because the Labor Party do not care whether a program is good or bad. The only thing that interests the Labor Party is how many seats they win. They could not care less about morality. They could not care less about what is right or what is wrong or what is good or what is bad. The only thing that matters to the Labor Party, as you see from Senator Schacht's interjection, is how many seats they won. That is all that interests them. They are not interested in whether the government does something good. They are not interested in whether this is a good program. They are not interested in the fact that this is something they never did in government. They are not interested in any of that. They are solely interested in whether Mr Smith won or lost his seat.

speech.para: We are interested in doing good things for the Australian community. It goes beyond the crudity of the politics that you see on the other side of the chamber. It goes beyond crude politics because what we are talking about is doing good things. Our commitment through the gold medal disability access program is very, very clear. There can be no hedging, fudging, misleading or obfuscation. This is a program they never had when they were in government. We put it in place when we got into government. That is the difference between the two. I say that our commitment to Paralympic sport should be judged on that. That is a very, very clear point.

While I am on the subject of Paralympic sport, I want to take the opportunity to pay tribute to the people who are involved in Paralympic sport. Some of them happen to be very close friends of mine. For example, Hamish McDonald is a great guy and Anton Flavell is another excellent athlete. I share Senator Lundy's concern that sometimes these people do not get the recognition in the general community that they ought to get. When you have athletes who are as talented as this, they ought to get more publicity. They ought to get more public recognition.

The government works very hard, but at the end of the day the media chooses who are going to be our athletic heroes. That is not something I can influence, no matter how much I believe that people like Hamish or Anton or Lisa Llorens should have more public recognition. No matter how much I believe it, it is not going to change the public perception unless the media is willing to change it. Just because Paralympic athletes have a low public recognition factor, it is not the fault of the government; it is in fact the fault of the media. I believe the media should accept some of their responsibility. They are slowly doing so. The fact that athletes like Neil Fuller and Louise Sauvage get some public exposure is excellent, is good, and it ought to happen.

I make one other observation about Paralympic sport: let us accept Paralympians for their dedication as athletes. Rather than saying, `They have all these terrible burdens,' why don't we say, `They train as hard as able-bodied athletes and they deserve the same recognition'? They deserve not special recognition but the same recognition. That I think is the real point about the Paralympics. The great thing about our Paralympians is that, when you go to the AIS and to any of the training venues where they train, the thing you have to observe is that they train like everybody else. It is not that they train specially; they train like everybody else.

It may be that people like Hamish McDonald, for example, who can do dips with a 45-kilo weight hanging off his waist, have extraordinary ability, extraordinary talent. I do not know any able-bodied athlete who can do dips with 45 kilos hanging off his waist. The point to make is: they train like everybody else. That is why they deserve recognition, not special recognition, not pity. They deserve our recognition and respect because of the talent and commitment they have, which is shared with the able-bodied athletic community as well. That is my view anyway.

The second matter that Senator Lundy raised in this motion today was that of republicanism. Let me make it very clear: we believe that the head of government in this case should open the Olympics. There is a reason why the head of government should open the Olympics: the Queen does not want to open the Olympics. Then you have a simple choice. Should it be the head of government or should it be the Governor-General? It is interesting to note that the view that the Prime Minister should open the Olympics is sharedâ

talk.start.para: âIt's a disgrace.

âSenator Lundy interjects from other than her seat. That view is not just held by this government but is shared by the New South Wales Labor Minister for the Olympics, Mr Michael Knight. As Senator Ellison notes, Mr Knight agreed with the proposition thatâ
âNo. He wants the President of Australia to open. You are a liar. You are lying.
âOrder! Senator Schacht, I ask you to withdraw that remark. It is unparliamentary.

âI withdraw, but I raise a point of order. Senator O'Chee is deliberately misleading the Senate. He did not point out that Mr Knight has said that they want the President of the Australian Republic to open the Olympic Games.
âThere is no point of order.

âThank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. There was no point of order. If Senator Schacht had not so rudely interrupted, I was going to say that it was Mr Knight's view that the Prime Minister should open the Olympics if the Constitution remained unchanged. Senator Schacht cannot help himself. He has to interject. He has to yell. He has to scream across the chamber. He always does it. The tragic thing, Mr Acting Deputy President, is that the quality of the interjection never gets any better. It is the view of Mr Michael Knight, the New South Wales Labor government's Minister for the Olympics, that if the Constitution remains unchanged the Prime Minister, as head of government, should open the games. That is very clear.

speech.para: Those on the other side of the chamber, however, want to somehow change all this. One of the most spurious reasons I can think of for wanting to change our Constitution to make this place a republic is that we are going to have the Olympics and therefore we should become a republic to celebrate the fact that we are going to have an Olympics. What do we do if we get the Olympics in another 20 or 30 years time? Change back to a constitutional monarchy to celebrate it again? Of course not. The Olympics is a great thing but, at the end of the day, it is a set of games. I love sport, but sport is just sport. Sport is not a reason to change the Constitution. I would hope that the collective intellect of the Australian Republican Movement could come up with a better reason for wanting to change the Constitution than that we are going to celebrate the Olympics.

The Olympics will last for a couple of weeks, but a republic is forever. For the short-sighted, short-lived and simple-minded notion that we should celebrate the Olympics, they want to change the Constitution. But a republic is forever. The changes they makeâthe ills they import into the changes in the Constitutionâwill be with us forever, for a long time after the Olympics are gone, after people have ceased to remember the great feats of heroism, the great failures or whatever happens at the Olympics. Long after those things have ceased to be part of the popular consciousness, long after the Olympic heroes have passed away, we will still be left with their constitutional follyâthe folly that we should change the Constitution simply because of the Olympics.

There have been all sorts of ridiculous arguments trotted out by the republicans. One of the best, and I think Senator Ellison will appreciate this one, laughable reasons why we should have a republic was to become more like our Asian neighbours and be better accepted in Asia. That is one of the most absurd propositions that has ever come forward. But, interestingly enough, that was never a proposition they made whenever they went to Japan. They never said to the Japanese Prime Minister, `Oh, by the way, we want you to know that our domestic constitutional policy is to change to a republic to be more like you,' because Japan is a constitutional monarchy.

In fact, if you look around the eastern Pacific area, there are as many constitutional monarchies and protectorates of constitutional monarchies as there are republics. If you asked me to make a choice as to where I would prefer to live, I would prefer to live in some of those constitutional monarchies rather than in some of those republics. If you asked me if I would prefer to live, for example, in the constitutional monarchy of Japan or the Republic of Indonesia, I know where there is better protection for the rights of the individualâit is in the constitutional monarchy of Japan. But by becoming a republic we do not become more or less like the rest of Asia. We do not become more or less like any of our Asian neighbours. Yet this was some of the absurd argument we heard being trotted out by the Australian Republican Movement.

What I point out to the republican movement is simply this: they should show us how becoming a republic makes Australia a better democracy. The bottom line is that they cannot, because by becoming a republic you immediately politicise the head of state if the head of state is directly elected. If he or she is directly elected, they have to go to the people with a platform and there is politics in it. Any time people stand for election, be it for the president of a republic or the president of a tiddlywinks club, there is going to be politics in it.

One of the flaws of the Republican Movement's proposal is that they take the highest office in the land, the unifying office of the landâthat is, the role of the Queen's representativeârip it apart and replace it with a republican model where half the people in the country are working politically to undermine the head of state. That, they think, is good, smart and intelligent politics. I say that it is morally and intellectually moribund to foist that sort of nonsense on the people of Australia.

Do we want to have in Australia in the future a repeat of the Bill Clinton-Monica Lewinsky scandal? Do we want to see the highest office in this country, if we become a republic, debased and dragged through the mud in some absurd scandal about who happened to be sleeping or otherwise entertaining the president? That is what they would do. In a political system where the head of state is popularly elected, half the people will be trying desperately hard to drag that sort of filth out into the public domain. That is what they would do.

Consider this other factor: you cannot become a popularly elected president without having a party political machine backing you. Suppose, for example, we had a Liberal or National Party president and a Liberal or National Party government and the government did something wrong. What is the probability that the president would sack the government? Very, very small, because the president would owe their party allegiance to the government.

Let us assume you take the other route. The other route is to say, `Look, we're going to have not a popularly elected president but an appointed president.' That is not making the country any more democratic and it does not better protect the people from the parliament. The role of the Governor-General is to protect the people from the parliament so that, in the event of a constitutional crisis, the Governor-General sacks all members of parliament and calls a fresh election and lets the people have their say.

Nothing in the idea of an appointed president makes that more likely, but the model that the Constitutional Convention threw up was one where the Prime Minister of the day could sack the Governor-General at any time, without any reason, without any trial and without any cause. Does that add to the stability of the government of Australia? The answer is no. It in fact adds to weakness and instability, yet that is what they want to foist upon us, that is what their argument is all about and that is why they are wrong. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI thought I would begin my contribution by reminding the Senate what we are debating today. After listening to that rave from Senator O'Cheeâand I think we now understand why the electors of Queensland had the good sense to decide that after 1 July he should not grace this placeâyou might be under a misapprehension that a very different issue is before the Senate. We are debating the question:

speech.para: That the Senate notes the inconsistency in the view of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) that it would be inappropriate for a non-Australian to open the Olympic Games, yet appropriate for a non-Australian to remain as Head of State.

Let me commence my contribution by saying that the Labor Party's view on this issue of who should open the Olympic Games has been quite clear. It is a simple one. It is guided by the fact that members of the Australian Labor Party both at a parliamentary and an organisational level unanimously advocate an Australian republic. It is a policy that is enshrined in the Labor Party's platform.

If a president is installed soon after the republican referendum paves the way for constitutional change then the president should open the Olympic Games. But there may not be enough time for such an inauguration to follow a resounding yes vote in a referendum, so as far as the Labor Party is concerned the fall back position should be, and I think this would be the view of all republicans, that without a president the Prime Minister of the day should open the Olympic Games. That is a very clear position. We are republicans. If there is no president then an Australian should open the Olympic Games. Her Majesty the Queen should not open the Olympic Games in Sydney in the year 2000. People may be astonished about this, but in relation to this situation we actually agree with the Prime Minister.

You would be aware, Mr Acting Deputy President, that as a senator one receives a great deal of correspondence from constituents. I do not normally come into the Senate chamber to read into the Hansard record correspondence I receive. I am going to make an exception on this occasion. It is not a long letter. I am going to read the first paragraph of one of the very many letters I receive and respond to as a senator representing the state of New South Wales. It is a copy of a letter sent to the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, after the last election by a constituent in Sydney. He has indicated that he did not receive a response even though he went through his local Liberal member of parliament. This is what the letter says:
Dear Prime Minister
Congratulations on your re-election. I often say to my children that if John Howard can become Prime Minister, anyone can.
I thought that is a very interesting letter to have received and an interesting sentiment that many Australians would embrace.

But today we are looking at what John Howard's position is on the monarchy. There seems to be a real conflict between his stated aim of a no vote in the republican referendum and this burning ambition he has to open the Olympic Games in Sydney. If there is one issue that really demonstrates the hypocrisy of John Howard and the hypocrisy which underlies so many actions of this government it is his appropriation of the job, the task, to open the Olympic Games in Sydney.

We now have John Howard continually undermining the republican referendum. What about this ill-judged, inadequate and overwritten preamble that he penned recently? It is so embarrassing to Australians. He backs the Australians for a Constitutional Monarchy. He stirs up the Direct Election Republicans as much as he possibly can. He is attempting to retain the Queen as Australia's head of state.
I noticed today a high priority wire story that says:
Prime Minister John Howard today signalled that he would scrap the idea of a Constitutional preamble altogether if his draft version was voted down in the Senate.

John Howard is saying, `Hang consultation, don't worry about what the other 18 million Australians might think.' If he does not get his own miserable petty little way he is not going to cop any preamble at all. That is the way John Howard and the Liberals do business.
But the same John Howard, the same Prime Minister, is perfectly happyâ
