talk.start.para: âOn a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: I understand the passion of the moment, but do you think that at some stage in the rest of Senator Faulkner's time he could actually use the Prime Minister's proper title as he is required to under standing orders? For the last six minutes he has studiously avoided addressing the Prime Minister in the proper fashion.
âI am sure Senator Faulkner is aware of the point you make.

âPrime Minister Howard is perfectly happy to hijack the Queen's role when it suits him and his politi cal purposes, because he knows Australians will not be impressed if Her Majesty the Queen opens Australia's Olympic Games. It seems to me that we have quite a similar situation to that of the Senate chamber, where, as I have said on many occasions, Senator Colston has stolen a Labor vote. On this occasion, it is Mr Howard who has stolen the Queen's role at the Sydney Olympic Games. I think that if Mr Howard was serious about being a monarchist, he would invite the Queen to open the Games. But there seems to be a significant dose of hypocrisy here in the actions of the Prime Minister. Mr Howard tells anybody who wants to listen that, when he was a mere shadow minister, he put his view on the record that the prime minister of the day should open the Olympics. He will add that at that time it could have been anybodyâit could have been Dr Hewson or Mr Keating or somebody else who could have been Prime Minister in the year 2000. I think that is a classic spin from Mr Howard on this issue.

speech.para: Mr Howard always had only one political objective, and that was to become Prime Minister of Australia. He never had a clue what he would do when he actually won the title, but he was always absolutely obsessed with becoming Prime Minister. I think he had a vision of himself as the monarchist Prime Minister opening the Olympic Games in Sydney. I suppose we could say that he has a similar sort of vision to that of Sir Robert Menziesâwhat would you expect from Sir Robert Menzies' heir? Mr Howard says that he is the most conservative leader that Australians have ever had. To be fair, I think you can say that if Mr Menzies was Australian Prime Minister at this time he would probably have ensured that it was the Queen up there on the podium and not the Australian Prime Minister who was opening the Olympic Games.

But, you see, this is the difference: Sir Robert Menzies was actually faithful to his own ideas. He genuinely believed in fulfilling his monarchist principles. He was faithful to the Crown. Mr Howard, on the other hand, is a monarchist when it suits his political objectives. I am sure Senator Schacht would agree with me that you would never have seen Sir Robert Menzies rudely shoving the Queen off the podium at the Sydney 2000 Games. That would have been a very unedifying display from Sir Robert and I expect we would never have seen it. Sir Robert Menzies, of course, believed utterly in the place of the monarchy in the Constitution of Australia. In 1956, when Sir Robert Menzies was Prime Minister, we had His Royal Highness Prince Phillip open the Games. For all the snivelling cant that we are so used to from Mr Howard, I never describe him as a monarchist these days; I always describe him as a Howardist. After all, he really is an opportunist through and through. He is a monarchist to the second last ditch, basically. If he can be a monarchist and also get on the podium to open the Olympic Games, that is fine by him.

I notice that Dame Rachel Cleland today has come out to absolutely bag the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, which may come as a surprise to many old-fashioned Menzies-era Liberals. I have heard of an ABC item which indicates that the Prime Minister has been accused of lacking vision for Australia. And this criticism has been made by 93-year-old Dame Rachel Cleland who, of course, is one of the Liberal Party's longest-serving members and widow of Sir Donald Cleland, who helped establish the party. She has a crack at all the major political parties, because she thinks they are out of touch, but she says the Liberal Party appears most backward. Dame Rachel makes the point that the Liberal Party is a far cry from the one that her husband helped create. Let me quote Dame Rachel today about the Liberal Party:
It was alive, vigorous, forward looking, looking into the future, quite different from what it is now.

What a condemnation of Mr Howard and the Liberal Party in 1999 from one of its great stalwarts! It is important to see how Mr Howard has managed to get himself into this situation of insisting on opening the Olympic Games. It is worth looking at the history of Olympic funding by the Commonwealth. In 1995, the then Labor government set the ball rolling with capital grants of $150 million to prepare the Homebush site, grants to training programs and the Olympic athlete program of $60 million, with a further commitment of Commonwealth money as the year 2000 approached. No-one in the Labor government had the hide to ask for the job of opening the Olympics. The Labor government attached no strings. The Games had been won by Sydney and Labor recognised that the Commonwealth had a responsibility to chip in with funding to get the infrastructure in place for the Games. It is a national responsibility when you hold the Games in Australia. In opposition Mr Howard of course promised to uphold every Olympic commitment that was made by the Labor governmentâevery one.

But when the Howard government took office, Mr Howard asked his tourism and Olympics minister, Andrew Thomson, to write to the new South Wales government with a list of demands. In return for handing over the funds already committed by Labor, the Commonwealth wanted blocks of tickets for guests, corporate boxes in the main stadium and in the superdome and a mooring for an Incat hydrofoil at Pier 7 in Pyrmont for a business hospitality centre, and they demanded that the Prime Minister open the games. Then those demands, of course, were sent to the New South Wales government in early 1998. Mr Howard's own department was responsible for the negotiations. In other words, what the Liberal government did was tie Commonwealth funding to a decision that Mr Howard open the gamesâMr Howard puffing himself up with all his pomposity and bombast on the podium so all Australians can be embarrassed in the international arena when they see him. No funding from the Commonwealth unless Mr Howard opened the Olympic Games.

Of course, that is the problem, and that is how this decision was relayed to New South Walesâno negotiation, no discussion, no consultation; just a threat from the Prime Minister. We know it was not an official cabinet decision, because I asked Senator Hill whether the Prime Minister had the support of his colleagues in relation to his demand that had been placed on the New South Wales government. Senator Hill, of course, in answer to my question said this:

To use the word `demand' is to somewhat overstate the position, but certainly the view that the Prime Minister of the day is the most appropriate person to open the games is one that is supported by the cabinet.

He said that it was not an official cabinet decision but had the unanimous support of ministers. I bet it was pretty embarrassing to all the cabinet ministers also to put their names and the cabinet's name to such an act of brazen hypocrisy on the part of Mr Howard.

And, of course, Mr Howard instructed that an official write to the New South Wales government and SOCOG, and he simply did this: he used millions of dollars of Commonwealth money, millions of dollars of public money, to lever himself up onto the podium at the Sydney 2000 Olympics. The Prime Minister of Australia has even removed the value of the blocks of tickets from the federal funding and, instead of providing $32 million to New South Wales for games services, as put in the 1997 appropriations bill, he has subtracted $1.2 million for that total. I do not know how tickets for federal ministers and, no doubt, Liberal Party flunkeys and supporters are defined as `funding for games services', but we will measure this at a later stage.

So a lot of money is being poured into this podium to give what I believe is a small-minded, miserable, poll-driven Prime Minister his brief moment of glory at the Sydney Olympics. I do not how much money it will take to jazz up the podium to make the Prime Minister look statesmanlikeâ

talk.start.para: âProbably about a 10-foot box to stand on.
âMaybe so, Senator Schacht. A lot of people will be watching this on television sets around the world. There will be Mr Howard, standingâyou are probably rightâ
âI will be listening to Roy and HG .

âYou will be listening to Roy and HG , but I tell you what, Senator Forshaw, he probably will be standing on a box to give himself a bit of temporary stature. People will ask all over the world, `Who on earth is that?' They will say, `I cannot believe that this guy is Australia's head of state.' And they will be right. He will not be Australia's head of state. The head of state, of course, is Queen Elizabeth II, and Mr Howard wants to make sure that she remains Australia's head of state. That is the sort of vision we have from this Prime Minister and from this government. Do not ever forget that Olympic motto, `faster, higher, stronger'. What is it nowâ`self-interest, hypocrisy, cant'? It has been redefined by Mr Howard and the federal Liberals.

speech.para: I think that if Mr Howard was true to his publicly stated commitment to the monarchy and was true to his word, then he would graciously invite the Queen to open the games. We do not want the Queen to open the games; we want an Australian to open the games. We want an Australian head of state to open the games. We want an Australian president to open the games. In the event that that is not the case, we do want the Prime Minister to open the games, but not a hypocritical, miserable, small-minded Prime Minister like the one we have.

talk.start.para: âMr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order.
âWhat do you object to?
âI ask that those insults, which are quite clearly unparliamentary, be withdrawn.
âSenator Faulkner, I think the use of the words `hypocritical' and `small-minded' might be in breach of the standing orders.
âAre asking me to withdraw them? Small-minded is not unparliamentary.
â`Hypocritical' has been asked to be withdrawn in the past.
âYou asked me to withdraw `small-minded' and `hypocritical'. I am happy to withdraw `hypocritical'.

âI rise to support the motion of general business today and to endorse the excellent contribution of our leader, Senator Faulkner. There is no doubt that this Prime Minister is at the least inconsistent in his views when it comes to the issue of the opening of the games and the future head of state of Australia. One could even go so far as to mention the word `hypocrisy', but we are not allowed to do that.

speech.para: In the absence of there being an Australian head of state at the time of the opening of the Olympic Games, I support the proposal that the Prime Minister open the games. I do so on the basis that that is the best alternative available and likely to be available at the time. It is the best alternative to the actual Australian head of state, namely, the Queen of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, herself opening the games.

We all know that the normal procedureâindeed, it has been the procedure, as I understand it, at every Olympics of the modern eraâis for the head of state of the country of the host city to open the games. But interestingly enough, for the Olympic Games that will herald in the new millenniumâthe Sydney Olympics in 2000âthat we in this country have the great honour to host, we have had to face this issue: who can we get to open our games? We were not able, apparently, to follow the tradition of the head of state opening our games. Why? Because whilst the Prime Minister personallyâand publicly, as he has statedâstrongly supports the maintenance of the current situation that our head of state is whoever is the head of state of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, nevertheless he knows that it would be totally unacceptable for a foreign head of state to open the Olympic Games in Sydney next year. He knows that that would be the signal to the Australian people and to the world that, when it comes to hosting the Olympic Games, we can put on the best show on earth but we have to get a foreign citizen and foreign head of state to open the games on behalf all Australians and all the athletes assembled.

The very fact that we are having this debate here this afternoon demonstrates the inconsistency in the Prime Minister's position on the republic. If we now had our own head of stateâan Australian citizen as the head of stateâthis issue would simply not have arisen. No matter how much I listen and how hard I try to understand the arguments of people like Senator O'Chee and other monarchists, including the Prime Minister, I cannot understand how they can say to the Australian people, `None of you is good enough to be the head of state of this great nation.' Apparently not one person out of 18 million Australians can qualify, according to our Prime Minister, to be the head of state. Rather, according to the Prime Minister, we have to rely upon a foreign country 20,000 kilometres away to determine who our head of state is. And further, we shall accept as our head of state and should continue to accept as our head of state whoever, on the basis of the accident of birth and the system of hereditary monarchy, becomes a future king or queen of England. We in this country apparently are not good enough, according to the Prime Minister.

Yet the Prime Minister believes that when it comes to the opening of the games, he is good enough to undertake that solemn task. He can push the Queen aside. This is not a gentle tap on the back to guide her into her seat. This is to push the Queen out of the road and take on the task himself of opening the Olympic Games, one of the most significant events in the history of this country. It really is a case of `Wham, bam but no thank you, ma'am.'

The Prime Minister's inconsistency when it comes to putting his own personal glory and his own ego before tradition extends into other areas of this debate. Let us look at his proposed preamble. The Prime Minister said that he would draft a preamble, and he has done so with the assistance of some peopleâbut he ignored the assistance of Les Murray when it came to all of the content of that preamble, and imposed his own willâand he has released that. But he has made it very clear that his is the preamble that we have to vote upon. He has made it clear that he will not accept or even listen to the views of the Senate. This is the same Prime Minister who, back on 8 June 1995, when responding to the proposal of Paul Keating, the then Prime Minister, to move towards an Australian head of state, said:

The great problem with the approach outlined by the Prime Minister last night is that he will not give you, the Australian people, the referendum question, that is the referendum option that you want. He will passâ
that is, Mr Keatingâ

through the parliament without your involvement the referendum proposal that he and he alone wants. He will then demand that you answer his question at a national referendum. Our approach is quite different. Our approach is to involve all of the Australian people at the beginning, the middle and the end of the process. Our approach includes all Australians. Our approach is to allow you to help decide the kind of Constitution the Australian people want for their future, not the kind of Constitution the current Prime Minister wants for your future. Our approach is to allow the people of Australia to decide not only the question and the options but also fundamentally the referendum itself.

What noble, pious words from the then Leader of the Opposition, our now Prime Minister Mr Howard! But those sentiments have been ignored. They have been thrown out when it comes to this issue of the preamble. Because, as I said, the Prime Minister has made it very clear that we have to cop his preambleâhis convoluted, disjointed, uninspiring piece of doggerel. No-one else can proffer a suggestion, and he will ignore the views of the Senate when that matter comes on for debate in this chamber. If we do not agree with his proposal, then he will say, `I'm sorry folks, but you won't get a vote after all.'

Of course, what the Prime Minister really wants with that attitude is to scuttle the preamble, to scuttle the referendum and to retain the existing Constitution and the existing foreign head of state. He wants to retain the preamble as it is currently worded in the Constitution. It reads:

WHEREAS the people of New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, Queensland, and Tasmania, humbly relying on the blessing of Almighty God, have agreed to unite in one indissoluble Federal Commonwealth under the Crown of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, and under the Constitution hereby established:
And whereas it is expedient to provide for the admission into the Commonwealth of other Australasian Colonies and possessions of the Queen:

Be it therefore enacted by the Queen's most Excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows:â

That is what the Prime Minister would like to continue to have in our constitution. As some of you know, I have been a student of English literature and I love English history, but it is a nonsense to suggest that we should retain a constitution that has as its preamble those historical relics. In my view it is a nonsense to suggest that we are not independent enough, not good enough as a nation, to have one of our own citizens as our head of state.

John Howard is big on tradition; he said so. But when there is a bit of personal glory to be gained, when he can appear on the world stage, on TV, watched by billions of people around the world, then tradition flies out the window. As Senator Faulkner said, he will not mind standing up there on the podium, or whatever else he is standing on, soaking in the glory and no doubt thinking to himself that there are a few hundred million people out there who think he is the head of state. That is why he let it be known, I believe, that he wanted SOCOG to call on him to open the Games. It seems that for this occasion he can ignore the Constitution; he can ignore the fact that the Queen is our head of state and that the Governor-General is her representative.

I note that the Prime Minister, in another somewhat sneaky manoeuvre, has invited the Queen to visit Australia. I think it is later this year or early next year that she is planning to come. I don't have any problem with that. I am not so sure that people regard such royal visits as all that relevant any more, but that is fine. We have visits from foreign heads of state and leaders from time to time. We have them visiting this parliament and the Prime Minister hosts a lunch for them. What always strikes you when you go to one of these functions for a visiting head of state or leader of another country? At the start of the proceedings our Prime Minister gets up and toasts the head of state of the visiting representative of the other country and then that person gets up and toasts our head of state. Who does that person toast? It is the Queen.

You should see the looks on the faces of the people assembled in this, the Australian Parliament House, in this great building, the symbol of real democracy and representation of the people. You should see the looks on the faces of even the diehard monarchists opposite. They cringe every time they see that. That should no longer happen.

Whilst the Prime Minister has invited the Queen to visit Australia, I don't think he has invited her to come to the Olympics. We know that she is not coming to the Olympics. There will be plenty of heads of state from other countries visiting the Olympics, I would imagine, but not the Queen of England. And why not? It might be a bit embarrassing if she is there cheering on the British athletes rather than the Australians.

In my remaining minutes I turn to some of the other inconsistencies that surround this debate about a republic. The arguments of Senator O'Chee and other monarchists both in the parliament and in the ACM, the Australians for a Constitutional Monarchy, are riddled with inconsistencies. For instance, they put up arguments like, `The Queen is the Queen of Australia and therefore that makes her a different entity from the Queen of England,' and, `We don't need to change our Constitution because our head of state is Queen Elizabeth II, Queen of Australia.' This is a spurious proposition. She is, by act of parliament, the Queen of Australia but she is still the Queen, the monarch, of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland.

talk.start.para: âShe is the Queen of Australia only when she is in Australia.

âThat is true. Senator Schacht reminds meâonly when she is in Australia. But the Constitution retains the provision that the head of state of this country is the monarch of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, her heirs and successors. Under the current constitutional arrangements, whoever her heir or successor is will become our head of state.

speech.para: Another inconsistent argument that is put up by the monarchists to try to divert people from looking at the real questionâthe real question being should we or should we not have an Australian as our head of stateâis that the Governor-General is really the head of state. I don't know how many times I have heard spokespersons for the monarchists argue that the Queen is the head of state and we should not change it because we have really got the best of all worlds; we have got a foreigner who does not live here and therefore we do not have any problems. Then they go to the proposal that she is the Queen of Australia. They even argue, `Well, no, the Governor-General is really the head of state.' They cannot put forward a logical, consistent argument, because there isn't one.

But even if it were to be the case that the Governor-General was the real head of state of this country, then why not make it absolutely official? Why don't the monarchists argue that we should get rid of the fiction in the Constitution so that it reflects what they claim is really the case? The reason they do not put that argument is because it is a spurious argument. It is a deliberate misrepresentation of the true legal position. I think one of the most spurious and, indeed, deceitful arguments put forward by those who seek to oppose an Australian becoming our head of state is the argument that we have a constitutional monarchy, that we have a stable system of democracy and that we should not change it because, if we do, chaos might follow. Our stable system of government in Australia is due very much to our democracy, to the fact that we are an island continent and do not share land borders with other countries and to the fact that we have never suffered the problem of invasionâthough the Aboriginal people would argue otherwise. But, most importantly, our stability is, I believe, due to the inherent character of the Australian people. It is not something that was bequeathed to us by the British monarchy. It is a nonsense to suggest that constitutional monarchies are good governments and are always stable and that republics represent the road to unrest and chaos.

Senator O'CheeâI heard his remarksâsaid that you politicise the office when you have a president of a republic. Senator O'Chee should go back and look at a bit of recent English history. The greatest political crisis this century in the United Kingdom occurred about 60 years ago when Prince Edward was the successor to the throne of the United Kingdom. But what happened? There was a huge political and constitutional crisis because he wanted to marry a divorced woman. The parliament effectively said at that time, `You cannot remain the king of England,' because it was believed to contravene the Act of Settlement of 1701. Prince Edward, the Duke of Windsor, was forced to abdicate. He could not continue his rightful succession to the throne. A huge political and constitutional crisis went on in England at the time. What happened here in Australia? We sat back, waiting, and wondering: `Who are they going to appoint as our future head of state?' Eventually, the British parliament, the politicians, forced Prince Edward, the Duke of Windsor, to give up his right to the throne and his brother was appointed as King George VI of England. The current Queen is the daughter of King George VI. So let us not have any of this nonsense that somehow constitutional monarchies are above politics and better than republics.

Anyone who knows anything about English constitutional history knows that parliamentary democracy in England came about as a result of overcoming the tyrannies of monarchsâyou have only got to look at what happened to Charles I to know that. Indeed, it is parliament that is supreme in that country. But in this country we are reliant upon whoever becomes the king or queen of England to be our head of state. That is, I believe, a situation that we should no longer have to accept. As the eyes of the world and the eyes of all Australians are upon us next year at the Olympics, we should be able to show the world that we are truly and completely Australian and that all Australians can aspire to be our head of state. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMight I say at the outset that Labor, in bringing forward this motion for debate today, really demonstrate what a pathetic opposition they have become. We are debating a motion of which Senator Carr gave notice as a general business notice of motion:

speech.para: That the Senate notes the inconsistency in the view of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) that it would be inappropriate for a non-Australian to open the Olympic Games, yet appropriate for a non-Australian to remain as Head of State.
I note that although Senator Carr gave notice of that motion, it was left to Senator Lundy to move the motion, so it shows how much faith Senator Carr had in his own motion.

The fact that Labor has brought forward this motion today demonstrates loud and clear just what a first-class job the Howard government is doing across its whole range of responsibilities. It demonstrates loud and clear that the Labor opposition is so bereft of real and substantial issues on any shortcomings on the part of the government which it can attack that it is reduced to attempting to fabricate an issue out of something that clearly is not an issue. The issues that it is trying to fabricate relate to, firstly, the Prime Minister's personal view on the most appropriate constitutional arrangements for Australia and, secondly, the Prime Minister's personal view on who should open the year 2000 Olympic Games being held in Sydney. Not only is the Labor Party showing that it is completely bereft of ideas and issues by bringing forward this motion but, in trying to beat up this matter into an issue today, it is showing how out of touch with the country at large it has become.

Where has the community demonstrated its concern about these matters? As far as the issue of the Constitution is concerned, about half the community, if not more, agrees with the Prime Minister's position on our present constitutional arrangements. I suspect that by the end of the year, when we hold a referendum, well over half the community will agree that our present constitutional arrangements, which have served Australia well for some 98 years, are quite adequate and quite appropriate for our future.

As far as the opening of the Olympic Games is concerned, the only references I can find to a concern about the Prime Minister opening these games are the comments of a couple of radio talk show hosts. There is no widespread concern in the community about the Prime Minister's position on either of these issues. This is clearly a Labor attempt to beat up an issue because, in regard to the matters which are of primary concern to the people of Australia and for which the government has responsibility, the government is clearly and demonstrably doing an outstanding job.

Let us not beat about the bush. When this government came to office a little over three years ago, the federal government finances were in an absolute mess. We faced an annual budget deficit of $10 billionâa $10 billion black hole. Yet, in less than three years in office, we managed to convert that deficit into a budget surplus by a combination of sound financial management and government restraint. As a consequence of that, and as a consequence of the government's generally sound financial management, the government has inflation at not an all-time low but certainly the lowest level it has been in the last 30 years. That was reinforced by the most recent inflation figures released yesterday. For the last three months, we have had an inflation rate of virtually zero. For the last 12 months it was something of the order of 1.2 per cent. It is an extraordinarily low rate of inflation, given the history of the last decade or so. Again, it is runs on the board for the present government.

As with inflation, interest rates are the lowest they have been for 30 years. Low interest rates are a benefit to home buyers. They reduce the monthly repayments for housing, leaving more money in people's pockets to spend on other goods and services. That has a flow-on benefit to the economy. That is why the economy has grown strongly over the last year or two. We have had record low interest rates in the last 30 years. We have seen unemployment falling as a consequence of that. As a consequence of increased demand and economic growth, unemployment is falling. As I mentioned earlier, we have achieved a budget surplus.

It is a very sound financial position for the government and a very sound position for our economy. I remind the Senate that low interest rates benefit not only home buyers but also business, and in particular small busines sesâmost of which operate on overdrafts or borrowings to sustain the activity of their businesses and, therefore, generate a real benefit and real opportunities for growth when they have low interest rates. Again, there are benefits to the economy. That, in turn, has meant that the rate of growth in Australia has been the highest of many of the OECD countries with which we have compared ourselves for the last year or two. In particular, this rate of growth has been sustained in the face of the Asian economic crisis.

Under the Labor Party, we became increasingly dependent on Asia as our main source of export income. Yet, firstly, because of the sound financial management of this government, and, secondly, because we have directed our trade activities on a broader front than just Asia, we have maintained a level of economic activity and a level of exports that have sustained that underlying strong economic growth and sheltered the Australian community from the outcomes of the Asian economic crisis. In particular, it has provided jobs growth rather than increased unemployment, which might have been the logical outcome of succumbing to those Asian economic problems.

In contrast to these policy initiatives, we find that the Labor Party is a complete policy free zone. Over the last 12 months or so, a couple of Labor parliamentarians have sought to generate some policy debate within the Labor Party, recognising that unless they have soundly thought through policies that they can put to the Australian people they have absolutely no chance of winning a future election. Mark Latham is one of those. The outcome for those individuals who have sought to facilitate a policy debate in the Labor Party is that they have been sent to coventry. They are not wanted in the Labor Party because the Labor Party is a complete policy free zone. It has no policies.

As I said at the outset, not only does the Labor Party have no policies; it has no issue on which to attack the government. The lack of issues is clearly demonstrated by the fact that they are putting up this motion today as a general business debate. It has also been generated in the Senate over the last couple of weeks and in the Senate since we began sitting after the last election. We have seen desperate attempts by the Labor Party to beat up into issues of concern issues that are not really there at all and certainly are not matters of concern to the wider community. We have seen them yet again try to crank up a scare campaign in this chamber on the GST as we debate the new tax system and the much needed tax reform legislation. They have not only beaten up a scare campaign; they have filibustered in that debate. Last night we saw from a senior Labor senator, Senator Ray, an exhibition of relevance deprivation syndrome perhaps even more evident than that whichâ

talk.start.para: âI raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I can take so much of this but Iâ
âWhat is your point of order?

âI will come to that, Senator Boswell. It is relevance, Mr Acting Deputy President. Is it sufficient in your view that a speaker can spend 10 seconds on a motion and then spend the rest of the time on the supposed sins of the opposition?
âOn the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy Presidentâ
âNo, Senator Chapman, I will rule on the point of order. There is no point of order because the debate has ranged far and wide. Therefore, there is no point of order.

âThank you for your support on that point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. If I had the chance to speak to it, I would have made exactly that point. The excerpts of the debate that I have heard have ranged far and wide, far beyond the narrow specifics of the motion before the chair. This matter that I am raising is relevant, because one must look at the motive that the Labor Party have in putting forward this motion. As I say, the motive is that they have nothing else to debate. There are no issues out there of real concern to the community. That is why the Labor Party are trying to fabricate an issue of this nature.

speech.para: As I was saying, we had this example of Senator Ray last night exhibiting even greater relevance deprivation syndrome than his colleague in the other place Mr Gareth Evans exhibited as a shadow minister. I guess Senator Ray, having been a senior and somewhat respected minister in the previous Labor government, would be experiencing that on the backbench. His relevance deprivation syndrome is such that his concerns these days are limited to what, where and with whom ministers in this government eat. That is the limit of the issues he is able to raise.

We have also seen question time in the Senate become an absolute non-event, with the Labor opposition being unable to raise issues of substance. Day after day we sit here as questions of no substance whatsoever are asked of government ministers, one after the other.

As I say, the reason for this motion being put forward today is that the opposition has absolutely no issues with which to attack the government; it has no policies to put before the Australian people to compare with the sound policies that the government has initiated and with which it has achieved results. So let us understand the reason for this motion having been put forward.

I turn to the issues that the opposition is trying to fabricate here: the issue of an Australian president replacing our present constitutional monarch, and the issue of who should open the Sydney Olympics in the year 2000. These issues really are quite unrelated. However, the Prime Minister's views on the Australian Constitution are well known. He has always expressed, and expressed strongly, his personal view that Australia should remain a constitutional monarchy. That is a view I share very strongly with him. Both the Prime Minster and I share the view that the constitutional monarchy has served Australia well for the 97 or 98 years since Federation and the Commonwealth government being established, that it does provide stability, that it has been able to deal with the occasional constitutional crisis that has arisen and that seeking to fiddle with the Constitution in the way proposed leaves it open to all sorts of unknown, and perhaps unintended, consequences. So, as I say, the Prime Minister's views on this issue are well known, and they are views that I share.

Nevertheless, the Prime Minister initiated a Constitutional Convention last year and accepted its outcome; he also accepted that that outcome would be put to the Australian people in a referendum, as it will be in November of this year. He has therefore fulfilled that commitment. That is as it should be. He has made that commitment, and he is fulfilling it. At the end of the day it will be the Australian people, not the Prime Minister, who will determine whether or not we abandon our current constitutional arrangements and establish a republic in Australia, with a president as the head of state rather than our current arrangements. That will be determined by that referendum in November of this year.

For that to occur, we have to have not only an overall majority of the Australian people vote in favour of those changes but also a majority of people in a majority of the states to approve amendments to the Constitution. A majority in at least four states will have to support the propositions for our constitutional arrangements to change. Again, that is proper and appropriate because the very foundation of our Federation in Australia is that the smaller states should have weight equal to that of the larger states in determining amendments to our Constitution and should not be dictated to by the larger states. That safety provision is there to ensure that there is general support for any significant changes to our Constitution.

The question of constitutional change is being addressed. But even if that referendum votes in favour of a republic for Australia, under the legislation that has been put through this parliament and which goes to the referendum, a president will not be in place prior to January 2001. So, first of all, we need to consider whether there will be a change. Secondly, we need to consider the timing of that change, if there is to be oneâand, as I say, it will not occur until 2001. Indeed, unless there are changes to the Constitution, the only option for any organising committeesâwhether organising the Olympics or any other major eventsâfaced with who to invite to officiate at functions remains the status quo.

Many functions and ceremonies take place on a daily basis throughout Australia, and always up for consideration is the appropriateness of who should open or officiate at those functions. Depending on the nature of the occasion, it may be appropriate for a mayor, a state premier, a state governor, a federal minister of the Crown or, indeed, the Governor-General to officiate at those functions; it may be appropriate for the Queen to be invited to do so, or it may be appropriate for the Prime Minister to do so. The fact is that it is the organisers of those functions who generally determine whom they would like to have conduct that opening ceremony.

In the case of the Sydney Olympics in the year 2000, the Sydney Olympic organising committee announced on 22 Aprilâthat is, only last weekâthat, should Australia have a president by the time of the games, the president, whether male or female, would be the person to open the games. However, the organising committee also stated very clearly that, if no such presidential office is in place by the time of the games, the Prime Minister will perform this role. As I said a few moments ago, we know for sure that, irrespective of the outcome of the referendum at the end of this year, the president, if we move to that form of Constitution, will not be in place by the time of the Olympic Games; he or she will not be in office until 2001. On that basis, and knowing that to be the case, the Sydney organising committee has made the final decision that it will be the Prime Minister who will open those Olympic Games.

The fact that the Sydney organising committee has selected the Prime Minister to be the officiating person underscores the point that these games belong to all Australians. The decision that the organising committee has made on this matter I am sure reflects the opinion of the general public that it is highly appropriate to have the Australian Prime Minister open the Olympic Games.

This is not a recent view on the part of the government, which shares the view of the Olympic committee and shares the view of the Australian people. As long ago as when Paul Keating was Prime Minister and John Hewson was Leader of the Opposition, the Liberal and National parties expressed the view that it would be appropriate for the Prime Minister of the day to open the Sydney Olympics. It was certainly reinforced by John Howard when he was Leader of the Opposition that, as the most senior and highest profile elected Australian figure, it was appropriate for the Prime Minister to open the Olympic Games.

This is not something that the Prime Minister has initiated since becoming Prime Minister to glorify himself in front of an international audience, as some have suggested. It has been a consistent view of the Liberal and National parties for some six or seven yearsâwell before there was any suggestion that John Howard might be Prime Minister or even that a Liberal Party leader might be Prime Minister at the time of the Olympic Games. It has been a consistent view, and it is an appropriate view. So let us have none of this nonsense that this has happened in the last year or two now that John Howard is the Prime Minister and that he has sought this apparent glory for himself.

As I said at the outset, there is no issue here at all. It is an attempted beat-up on the part of the Labor Party because they currently have no issues that are of concern to the general Australian community to raise in the Senate. The people are satisfied with the very good government they are getting from the Liberal and National Party coalition and the leadership that Prime Minister John Howard is providing.

With regard to the attempt to beat up this issue, the two issuesâthe constitutional position and the position of who should open the Olympic Games in Sydney in the year 2000âare quite unrelated. They are separate issues. Indeed, the views of the Prime Minister on these matters are private. He is not expressing the view of the government with regard to the Constitution. As I said, on behalf of the government, he has initiated a constitutional referendum which will give the people of Australia the opportunity to determine our future constitutional arrangements. Similarly, his view that the Prime Minister should open the games is a view that he has held for a long time. It is a view that the Liberal and National parties have held for a long time and have publicly expressed, irrespective of who the particular holder of that office might be at the time the games came around.

So let us have none of the nonsense that has been put up in this motion. It does not stand scrutiny. It is an attempt to beat up an issue that does not exist. It is about time the Labor Party got a hold of some real issues, but there are none. They should at least do some solid policy work and look for some policies that they could put to the Australian people that might give them some chance of garnering some support, which they sadly lack at the moment.

talk.start.para: âThe question here is whether there is inconsistency between the Prime Minister's view that we should remain a monarchy and his view that he, as elected Prime Minister, should open the Olympic Games, which, under the rules of the International Olympic Committee, are opened by the head of state. Clearly, there is an inconsistency.

speech.para: If one believes that Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth is the proper head of state, one should be pursuing a request for Queen Elizabeth to be there at the Olympic Games to read out the 13 or 15 words which are the required opening speech. The International Olympic Committee must have learnt from experience to give the heads of state no latitude but to read out a simple opening statement of two or three sentences. That does the job without having a captive audience held to a long speech from a politician who cannot help herself or himself. Whichever way this turns out, it will be a very short, succinct opening speech, and I do not think that is going to worry Australians too much.

The opportunity to open the games was too great for the Prime Minister, and he sees himself in that position, on that podium, on the night next year in Sydney delivering those 15 words. I am not unduly fussed about that. But, seeing we are in transition between being a monarchy and becoming a republic, I think the proper thing would have been for the head of state in Australia, the Queen's representative, the Governor-General, to read that speech.

Towards the end of his speech, Senator Chapman, who was the last speaker, said that in the last six or seven years there had been general agreement between the government and the opposition that events such as the Olympics ought to be opened by the Prime Minister, the elected head of government of the day. This is a very significant innovation. I do not think Australians will agree with that. Either we have a head of state or we do not have a head of state. I think Australians would have been terrifically proud to have the non-political head of state, Sir William Deane, opening the Olympics next year. I think it would have given everybody a very warm feeling.

There is the rough potential that some people will see an elected Prime Minister as not being their cup of tea when the time comes. I am not unduly worried about that. It will be a great event. Australians will be riveted by it, and I think they will be much more interested in the pyrotechnics and the display under the floodlights at that magnificent new stadium than they will be in the 15 seconds or so in which the Prime Minister delivers the prewritten opening words.

We are moving inevitably and ineluctably to becoming a republic where the functions of the current Governor-General in general terms will become those of the elected head of state, the president. Therefore, in this transition period, it is logical that the person to open the Olympics is the Governor-General. It is a missed opportunity, and I think the Prime Minister would have been seen as being more generally committed to the idea of Australia moving on had he requested that the Governor-General perform this function. He wants to undertake it himself. I do not think it is a matter of enormous moment. I hope that, when the day comes, he gets enjoyment out of reading the opening words, and I am sure Australians will feel terrifically proud and happy about that event taking place.

What about the head of state, though? What is going to be the relationship between the Prime Minister and the president when that time comes? I am one of those who are concerned that we are seeing a move towards the prime ministers of the day seeking the advantage of office to not only invade the role of the elected head of stateâparticularly at ceremonial functions, such as the opening of the Olympicsâbut control the future presidential office. That is a matter of great concern.

In the upcoming referendum, as a consequence of the deliberations of the Constitutional Convention, we are going to be voting for a president who will be elected by a two-thirds majority of a joint sitting of the two houses of parliamentâthe Senate and the House of Representativesâafter a process of selection and agreement by the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition and a selection panel. What people do not know is that it is not incumbent in this arrangement for there to be a two-thirds majority to dismiss the president. The Prime Minister can simply, by signing a letter of dismissal, dismiss the president summarily. It does not matter how correct or how popular the president has been; if he or she gets the Prime Minister's nose out of joint, the Prime Minister will be able to dismiss the president.

talk.start.para: âIf you don't like it, vote no.

âSenator Boswell, I am a staunch republican. The national meeting of the Australian Greens held a month ago here in Canberra also thought that was not a proper processâthat if it requires a two-thirds majority of parliament to appoint the president, it ought to require a two-thirds majority of a joint sitting of parliament to dismiss the president. I say to Senator Boswell, through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that I will be moving and fighting very strongly, when we get the opportunity in this place, to tighten up this measure to ensure that is the case.

speech.para: I understand that that intention was put forward in about 1986 when this real debate about the republic in its most recent chapter was set off by the writings of Professor George Winterton, the constitutional specialist. When former Prime Minister Keating set up a commission to look into how the president might be appointed, again it was said it should be a two-thirds majority of parliament to elect the president and a two-thirds majority of parliament to dismiss the president. When the Australian Republican Movement was approaching the debate at the Constitutional Convention, it also thought it should be a two-thirds majority to elect the president and a two-thirds majority to dismiss the president.

I am not going to go into the complexities of that Constitutional Convention, but something happened there. Remember that half the representatives at the Constitutional Convention were not elected by the people but were appointees, and a good number were not republicans but were pro monarchy. Whatever they were, out of that Constitutional Convention came the result we have, which is a dramatic change to the safeguards of the office of president and a dramatic increase in the vulnerability and the capture by the Prime Minister of the office of president. I think this is bad for our democracy and this is bad for the prospect of Australia as a republican democracy. I will be fighting very strenuously on behalf of the Greens, not only in this place but in the public arena, to have this altered so that we go back to the manifestly fair and proper process of ensuring that parliamentâand not the Prime Ministerâis the agent that appoints the president and is able to remove the president.

The issue has been raised of what we do if a president takes leave of her or his sensesâif, suddenly, a president is putting out some edict that is obviously not a sensible one for Australians. First of all, there is no law to prevent prime ministers going off on a tangent and doing foolish things. But if that is the case, let the Prime Minister have a suspensory opportunity for some days while parliament is recalled, and then parliament can determine whether the president's behaviour can be justified or not. The president would obviously be given an opportunity to account for what she or he is doing, and then parliament would deal with the request from the Prime Minister that this president be dismissed. What we are dealing with here, by the way, is a very, very unusual and unlikely situation, but it worries some people.

We can recall parliament within a matter of days in this age of modern, rapid transport and communications. In those circumstances, parliament can be recalled rapidly and can deal with a crisis that has arisen. I think a far worse crisis occurs if we leave it to the Prime Minister, in a period of disagreement with the president, to simply sign a document saying, `You are dismissed.'

It is a little worse than that because, in that circumstance, there is no way parliament can reappoint the president, put the president back in office. There is no provision for that under the presidential arrangements that are being put at the referendum in November. What would happen is that the Prime Minister, having dismissed the president, would appoint an interim president and then we would go through the process of having a new round of selections with parliament reappointing somebody by a two-thirds majority.

This is totally unsatisfactory. It is wrong. I do not believe Australians would support it. I do not know whether this was put into the arrangement as a means of shaking the confidence of Australians that they were getting a good arrangement for the new head of state. Whatever, it needs ironing out. I hope that all parties listening to this are having a rethink about this matter so that when it does come up in the Senateâpresumably just after winterâand when I move the amendment to put things right, there will be support in this place to see that we get it right because I think the current formula is very short of the mark and would not be one that people in Australia would like to see.

Yesterday I had the pleasure, together with Mr Gareth Evans and Senator Stott Despoja, of releasing an alternative preamble proposed for the Constitution of Australia. We know that the Prime Minister released his version of the preamble a short while ago. I want to talk about that for a moment. It is my view that the best preamble is one that will come from the people, with maximum consultation. I am aware that there is a very wide range of views in our community and that we have to take all of them into account. But it is also a matter of great symbolism and a great opportunity to reflect the Australia that people hold in their hearts through these few sentences at the front end of our Constitution.

I want to make it clear that I have not entered into supporting an alternative from this side of the Senate with a view that it is that or nothing. I do not believe that is a good process. That is why I have been strong in supporting the provision in the letter going out to newspapers about this preamble alternative that the Centennial Constitution Foundation be asked to look at the proposed alternative preamble and at input coming from Australians to the web site, which is being advertised in that letter, to improve it. This preamble is not set in concrete. It is an alternative. It is drawn from the previous input of hundreds of Australians into the work of the Centennial Constitution Foundation. That is a good group of people to be looking at further deliberations on further input from Australians.

I personally think we can go a step further and a step better than the Prime Minister's proposal, though it has support from many Australians and though his thinking is obviously very strong in that preamble option. I think a preamble ought to be simple. It ought to be stirring. It ought to reflect the Australia that people have a feeling for now. It ought to reflect something of our history and certainly reflect our hope for this great nation as we go into the next century.

I want to make it clear that this is not an exclusive bid to topple the Prime Minister's alternative. I have written to the Prime Minister this afternoon expressing that sentiment. I understand that on Adelaide radio station 5AA earlier today the Prime Minister indicated that we may well be looking at there being no preamble because his may not get through the Senate, although he has mooted the possibility of changes. But I seize upon his terminology of common ground, that we ought to be able to find common ground on this. I have written asking him to meet about this to talk about how we do that. I think that is again what the Australian people would want. We as parliamentarians ought to be the conduit for national sentiment in drawing up a preambleâwe have to put ethos in front of ego, in shortâand not the arbiters of what that shall be.

I am very happy with the idea that the Centennial Constitution Foundation, having done a lot of work on this already, be the people who give advice on the final form of that preamble. I hope that all involvedâand we are all involvedâcan give, can concede and can embrace the ideas of others who do not think exactly the same way, so that we do get a preamble that reflects as far as possible that diversity of feeling in Australia, and recognise this: that we all love this country, that we all want to appreciate the symbolism which reflects that love of this nation from whichever place or point of view we might have come.

Senator Chapman said earlier that this was a debate taking place which could have better be taken up by more important issues. I want to finish by saying that at lunchtime I was at the press conference which announced the end of the Australian Youth Policy and Action Coalition. This is a representative forum and research organisation for the views of young Australians. It had representation from groups right across the spectrum, from Scouts to YMCA, YWCA and so onâcommunity groups of great diversity in the nation and young people all. Now it is dead because government funding has been withdrawn. I think that is a matter of importance.

In particular, we have to draw on the thinking of young Australiansâand what a great lot of ideas that have come from them on the preambleâon the direction they see this country needs to take, on their ideas on meeting the problems that they undoubtedly face in this vast, materialist and fearful age, and on how we can overcome the fact that this is the first generation probably in all of human history of youngsters who have been robbed of hope. If we are charged with one duty in our time as elected representatives, it is to put into place the road back to hope for young Australians. I believe that implicitly charges us with the duty to think of future generations and to take into account their welfare in everything we do.

It is a very sad thing indeed that the government has cut the ground from under this youth forum at a time when tax concessions are going to strengthen the lobbying ability of groups like the Australian Mining Industry Council, the National Association of Forest Industries and so on in the precincts of Capital Hill. There it is. It is one of those things we will have to fight for a come back on. But I give a word of praise to those young Australians who have taken part in AYPAC and given such advice to the body politic in past times. I will be working as much as I can to see an early reconstitution of that body representing youth.

talk.start.para: âWe are debating a Labor motion which reads:

speech.para: That the Senate notes the inconsistency in the view of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) that it would be inappropriate for a non-Australian to open the Olympic Games, yet appropriate for a non-Australian to remain as Head of State.

I have been a member of the Constitutional Convention, I have listened to a lot of debates on it, and there are many inconsistencies in the republican debate. But they are not to be found in the views of the Prime Minister, nor of the people who really want to defend the present system of government. The inconsistencies are to be found in the ranks of the ALP, who have become fixated by a term which is not even in our Constitution. This very motion is inconsistent.

Our Constitution makes no reference to a head of state because, ultimately, the power resides with the people. That is where the National Party wants it to remainâwith the people. So we are staunch defenders of the current system of government. Neither are the Olympic Games mentioned in our Constitution. It is up to the nation as a whole through its representatives and its democratic system to make its own decisions about who opens what, who will be toasted at official functions here or there and who will be seated first, second and third. Those are niceties and diplomatic protocols, but they have nothing to do with a debate about how political power is shared and kept in check by popular sovereignty. The Olympics have nothing to do with a debate on constitutional change, except in one instance: if there was a constitutional change to a republic, then the PM could always sack the president, and who is going to open the games then?

The Labor Party is confused. Australia is quite independent and able to determine its own way on the games opening without the need for a republican constitution. The focus on and the potential power given to this new constitutional creation of a head of state actually detracts from the fundamental role of the people. Until former Prime Minister Paul Keating turned a dinner party topic into a political red herring to try to divert the country from focusing on the recession it had to have, and for which he has since admitted he was wrong, most Australians had never heard of the term `head of state'. A head of state is a movable feast. It can mean anything to anyone. Senator Carr's version would be very different to Senator Faulkner's idea of a head of state. A head of state might be a dictator, a king, a bishop, a president, a prime ministerâeven a grand duke. A head of state might have very little power, as in the Irish system, or absolute control, as in the American system. It resists clear definition.

I now turn to the two greatest enemies of humankind this century. Hitler referred to himself as a head of state, while Stalin did not. The Soviet Union even had 24 heads of state. I bet they did not all turn up to open the games in Moscow. The point is that all this rhetoric about a head of state obscures the very real and very serious changes which would occur if Australia became a republic. They would not just be surface changes but ones that change the very core of our system of government and the checks and balances we hold so dear in this country and which act against the abuse of power.

There are further inconsistencies implied by this motion. Senator Carr supports the proposition that the functions of the Governor-General should be transferred to a president. Somehow in that process the magic wand is waved and the president becomes a head of state, although Senator Carr would argue that the Governor-General never was a head of state. Republicans argue that the president would do the same thing as the Governor-General but that somehow the president gets to be a head of state as well. Strangely, too, the functions of the Queen, who Senator Carr argues is the only head of state currently, are not transferred to the president. I ask Senator Carr: how can the president be a head of state?
Professor David Flint, National Convenor of Australians for a Constitutional Monarchy, explains further:
The Queen's role in the appointment of the President will in fact be transferred to the politicians collectively in a joint sitting of parliament.
Perhaps that would mean that we would all be joint heads of state, from Senator Carr to Senator Brown to myself, because we are then going to have the power. Professor Flint continues:
The Queen's role in the dismissal of the President will be transferred to the Prime Minister.

Does that mean that the Prime Minister is also part of this many-headed monster that goes by the name of `head of state'? Should the whole parliament turn up to open the Olympic Games? That is just farcical. It just goes to show the fragility of any argument for constitutional change based on the head of state artifice.

The inconsistencies of Labor on the republican debate are endless. They have not been able to come up with a decent model over the whole decade this debate has been trundling along but have been pushed into an appearance of life by some white wine socialists. There have been disagreements over the most fundamental issue of the manner of appointing or electing a president, whether by parliament or by popular vote. The first Keating-Turnbull model for a republic would have made Australia like the present fifth French republicâwith two powerful competing politicians, the President and the Prime Minister.

The second Keating-Turnbull model goes the other wayâit does a complete 180 degree turn and makes the president completely vulnerable to the whims of a prime minister, as Senator Brown alluded to. In no other democratic republic is the Prime Minister able to sack the president at any time for any reason, or for no reason, and with no notice or right of appeal, as Senator Brown has pointed out to us. Professor Flint has also stated:
A rule change which allows one of the captains to send off the referee when he's about to rule against that team will be recognised as the rort it so clearly is.

Under such a scenario, would it be at all correct to describe that powerless president as our head of state, an office that is so under the thumb and in the power of others? Wouldn't it be more correct under those circumstances to denote the Prime Minister as the head of state? (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âOrder! The time allotted for the consideration of general business notices of motion having expired, the Senate will proceed to the consideration of government documents.
âI seek leave to incorporate the rest of my speech in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The remainder of the speech read as followsâ
In that case, it would be consistent under either a republic or constitutional monarchy for the Prime Minister to open the Olympic Games!

But seriously, the Prime Minister has long held the view that the Prime Minister of the day should open any Olympic Games. He has expressed that view long before he became opposition leader, let alone Prime Minister. It is a considered view which has nothing to do with arguments about heads of state or republics. It is not in conflict with the constitution. As a good Constitution does, ours gives us the freedom to determine our own way on these things.

As the Prime Minister himself said of his long held view: `I felt that as the most high profile elected Australian figure, the Prime Minister was the appropriate person to do it.' I think most if not all Australians would agree with that view.

To attempt to tie that view up with the Prime Minister's known opposition to a republic, is misleading, illogical and like comparing apples with oranges. There is no inconsistency between a Prime Minister opening the games and the existing constitutional system of government. All Labor achieves by this pathetic twisting and misrepresentation of views is to let down the republican cause.

Now I know some of my coalition colleagues hold different views to the National Party on the issue of a republic. I do not agree with them but I respect that they sincerely hold these different views. And I feel very sorry for them today because Labor's strategy is obviously to politicise the republic issue. In doing so they put at risk the cross party support required to have the faintest hope of getting the republic referendum passed. So while I am happy for Senator Carr to raise these sorts of issues time and again and give me plenty of opportunity to expose the flaws of the republic, I have to say that he will only do the cause of republicans everywhere a disservice. Is it really a republic which Labor wantsâor to score political points?

It is rather pitiful that of all the important issues facing us these days, this is all Senator Carr and the opposition can come up with. Come back to the front bench, Senator Ray. Your party needs you. What a wasteâsitting up the back in charge of the dirt files. When you could be doing so much to come up with a policy or two and some direction for your party from up the front. All Senator Ray gets to do now is to run guerilla attacks from the mountains of the back bench and pick on some decent National Party ministers only trying to do their job.

debateinfo.title: ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION AND BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION BILL 1998 [1999]

subdebateinfo.title: Report of Environment, Communications, Information Technology and the Arts Legislation Committee

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 27 April, on motion by Senator Eggleston:
That the Senate take note of the report.

talk.start.para: âI briefly want to speak to the motion to take note of the report of the Environment, Communications, Information Technology and the Arts Legislation Committee on legislation that the government has before the Senate. The Senate is aware that at the moment there is a great deal of concern in the community about this legislation.

speech.para: I want to reiterate that, if the change to the laws proceeds, we will have environmental powerlessness at a national level unseen since before 1972 when Lake Pedder in Tasmania was flooded. At that time the then incoming Prime Minister said that he did not have the constitutional powers to do anything about it although it was against the national interest that such a national heirloom and national park should be flooded for a hydro-electric scheme to produce one-tenth the output of a large mainland power station.

If this legislation proceeds we are going to be back in a situation where the federal government gives up its powers to intervene to protect this nation's heritage heirlooms, particularly where they do not have world heritage protection. It is not going to be possible, for example, for a federal minister or Prime Minister to nominate a place in Australia for world heritage listing as required under the provisions of the World Heritage Convention without the assent of the relevant state government, and that means the relevant state premier. So we are going to be in the position where the protection of Australia's heritage is going to be at the whim of a Robin Gray or a Joh Bjelke-Petersen or even a Richard Court or the current Tasmanian Premier, Jim Bacon.

Under the provisions of this legislation the Franklin River would have been flooded because the federal government would have been powerless. Under the provisions of this legislation the Daintree rainforest would have been chainsawed down instead of being proclaimed a world heritage area. Under the provisions of this legislation we would not have seen the protection of the Lemonthyme and southern forests of Tasmania. Under the provisions of this legislation we are basically disempowering the federal government. The federal government is basically disempowering itself of responsibility.

This is at a time when the federal government and indeed the Labor opposition are moving to dismantle state powers in order to improve the reach of the corporate sector and make it easier for investment into and out of Australia, to get rid of barriers to trade and commerce. At this time it is disempowering itself in its vital need to protect the nation's environment.

I might add, it is disempowering itself to be able to act properly to tackle international problems like global warming because the state governments are basically going to be able to obfuscate any federal move to adequately deal with the problem of global warming at a national level.

It is rotten legislation. It is a throwback. It has obviously come about from the pressure of the corporate sectorânot least the resource extraction industries, such as the woodchip, the mining and the fisheries industries. The input to the committee and the reports from the committee underline the alarm there is about this, in particular amongst the non-government organisations who are fighting for the environment in this country.

I have no confidence whatsoever that we are going to see future federal governments use their corporations powers to intervene to prevent maverick corporations from doing the wrong thing by the environment. Prime Minister Bob Hawke briefly entertained that idea back in the mid-1980s but was very quickly disavowed of it through pressure from the corporate sector. We are seeing here a dismantling of environmental powers at the federal level at just the time when they are required because of the raised environmental sensitivity of Australians and because of Australia's obligations to the international community. So it is a matter of extreme importance that the public be made aware that the environment is being let down by the government and in particular by the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Robert Hill, who has brought this legislation into this place.

It is remarkable that under the Westminster system, where the minister for the environ ment ought to be going into cabinet advocating for environmental powers to meet the aspirations of Australians in this age, he is actually going into cabinet with a document to do away with his own powers and replace them with much lesser powers so that the corporate sector will not have to worry about the environment or the impact of federal intervention because of pressure from the Australian people. It is a matter that needs a great deal of public canvassing. Most of the Australian public are unaware that the minister for the environment, presumably at the behest of the Prime Minister and certainly of the cabinet of this government, is basically handing across environmental powers to the corporate sector. The corporate sector is well aware that they can much more easilyâthrough their sheer wealth, lobbying power, access to legal power and so onâsway state governments than they can sway federal governments having to abide by federal laws. The outcome is a disastrous one for the environment.

The Australian Greens, along with environmental groups, are fighting hard to oppose this legislation. We are concerned to see that when it comes into this Senate, it gets a very thorough going through indeed. The Greens are preparing amendments to legislation which should not be here in the first place. We are going to do the job of the minister for the environment for him. He obviously cannot act on behalf of the environment. He obviously does not act on behalf of the environment. He obviously is selling out his portfolio obligations for the environment in cabinet. He would not have this legislation before the Senate were he a responsible advocate for the environment. We are obviously going to have to do his job for him.

The problem for us is that most Australians do not know that this insidious and disempowering legislationâwhich so threatens the Australian environmentâis before this place. It is about to come on for debate at any time once the GST legislation goes through or other priorities, such as the budget, are finished. In fact, the minister for the environment has seen that this is No. 3 on the list of 27 or so bills we are to deal with between now and June. I have no doubt that he has looked at the numbers and believes that he can get the support of Senator Harradine and Senator Colston to get this legislation through before 30 June. He knows that he would have no chance of getting it through afterwards. He is going to get a fight. It is going to be a long debate. This legislation is going to be dissected piece by piece, clause by clause, subclause by subclause, when it comes into this Senate. It is far too important to be dismissed.

The input to this committee shows how important it is to the people of Australia and their representatives, although it may not be given high priority by the government of the day. I do not know how strongly the Labor opposition, or indeed the Democrats, are going to fight against this or whether they are simply reduced to trying to amend it. The legislation is inherently wrong and should be opposed. That is what we will be doing when it comes before this placeâwith this report under our arms, because it reflects the fears and the anguish of environmentalists right around the country about this particularly bad piece of legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
