talk.start.para: âOrder! Consideration of committee reports and government responses has now concluded. I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: âYesterday the Senate witnessed an extraordinary display from one of this chamber's most respected political strategists and ministerial performers under Labor. It is a very sad thing to see a senator with such a capacity for positive contribution come into this chamber and indulge in an unworthy character assassination of political opponents. Not only did his actions diminish those he specifically targeted; they diminished all of us.

speech.para: Senator Ray's own reputation has suffered. I have frequently considered that his move to the back bench was too soon. I think back a couple of years ago to those heady days when Labor ministers could actually hold their own in this chamber. There was Button, Walsh, Evans, Richardson and Ray. They were Labor's powerful and strong leaders, and they commanded a government and their party.

But what we see today is a ramshackle frontbench and a backbench resorting to dirt files, because they are leaderless, rudderless and policyless. I thought it was a waste of time to have Senator Ray sitting on the back bench with all of that talent. Now I am going to revise that assessment. It has been known, of course, that after a period of glory as a minister senators and members return to opposition and become embittered. We have all seen that on both sidesâangry, grumpy old men who cannot let go and have to be continually negative. That should not happen to such a person as Senator Ray, and I find it sad and regrettable.

But what have these attacks on the National Party achieved? They have set in train, inevitably, a series of counterattacks. It has been revealed by senators on this side of the chamber that Labor ministers did exactly the same sorts of things as did National Party ministers, because the guidelines have not changed. Already, senators who have suffered in the past from these kinds of attacks have been brought into this episode as well. Will we not ever learn? What has been achieved but a further battering of the image of parliamentarians? The price is very high, and the reward is short-term political gain that will inevitably rebound. The public react to the headlines one day and then do not get to read the real facts a week later which show that there was nothing sinister after all.

Just a couple of nights ago a person rang me up, and I understand that he also rang Senator Gibbs. The call was quite threatening in nature, and the caller was clearly under the impression that we were all a bunch of so-and-sos. There will always be some who abuse the system, and a need to improve accountability is there. But I firmly reject that all too prevalent view that we are all here to sit around and do nothing but waste the taxpayers' money. I never thought that of Senator Ray, and I hope Senator Ray does not think that of me either. But I say to Senator Ray, `Your actions are only helping to foster that general perception out in the wider community. Your actions only serve to help radical groups like One Nation get into parliament.' These kinds of attacks simply reinforce the prejudices which get the David Oldfields of this world elected. By all means, expose the bad and the ugly where it can reasonably be said to exist, but do not be selective. Make sure it is really there, and that the facts live up to your own subjective assessment. Senator Ray did not follow the unwritten rule in this place that when you are about to be highly critical of someone you at least have the courtesy to let them know, as I have with Senator Ray tonight.

talk.start.para: âThere weren't any senators involved.
âBut you could have rung their offices.
âThey are in the Reps. They can't sit here.

âThey cannot sit here, but they can turn on the television and listen. I have contacted two of the three ministers' offices involved, and they say that there was no such contact. So there was no way that they could defend themselves, as they had the right to do, or have me come in and defend them.

speech.para: There is also the curious feature of this attack, that it is aimed fairly and squarely at the National Party. I really would like to know why that is. Senator Ray told the Senate yesterday that it was because previous experience has told us that they are the ones who get their snouts in the trough, first up and the biggest. What previous experience? That is simply highly offensive nonsense that says more about the speaker than it does about the subject.

There are pages of material which show how Labor ministers did exactly the same thing. It presumably was not wrong then, so why is it being painted as some kind of heinous sin now? Ministers are entitled now, as then, to cover the cost of expenses incurred providing hospitality on appropriate occasions in the course of official business. Ministers do not have credit cards or accounts, and the department determines legitimate expenditure in accordance with Labor's guidelines. Labor ministers claimed expenses for taking out ACTU members, CPSU members, John Laws, media representatives, peak industry groups and official and departmental staff at restaurants around the country. I have got the documents, but I am not going to name them.

talk.start.para: âYou can't name me, Ron.
âI cannot name you, and I am not intending to name you. But when I say `ACTU' it would be the same as the National Party taking out their electorate council.
âWe didn't criticise you for taking out business leaders.

âBut what I am saying is: if you criticise us, take the plank out of your own eye. There were even claims for events hosted by a minister's staff but not attended at all by any ministers. What does Senator Ray say to that? He would say a lot if it was the National Party but he said nothing of his own side. It is the nature of this place that when you are attacked you have got to fight back or you will be considered a soft target the next time. But it is a pandora's box that gets opened and all sorts of people get hurt, as we have seen. I am not going to name the people that we have information on. I do not think it warrants it. I do not think they did anything particularly wrong. I think the ACTU thing was a bit off. But, for goodness sake, let us bury this now. If there are any capital offences, present them, but do not put one side against the other side when they both do the same things. I consider taking someone out to lunch is not a heinous offence.

âI thank Senator Boswell for notifying me in advance, but I do not accept his criticism that I should have notified National ministers in the House of Representatives. That is not the tradition. The material that I had yesterday came to me very late. It came to me after 146 days wait. It came to me during question time. Only today did I get Mr Anderson's meal expenses. I will be equally critical of anyone on the Labor Party side that transgresses in this way as I will be of the Nationals. Senator Abetz said earlier today that I deleted that information. I simply did not have it.

speech.para: It is curious, though, that this government, against all convention and without permission, can go back and dig into Labor files and add that to answers to questions that were not asked. But that is fair enough. They have done that with three ministers and they have hardly laid a glove on any of the three ministers. But I want to say this, for once and the only time I will probably ever say it. Senator Boswell asks what I am doing on the back bench. Am I embittered? I do not think I am embittered. The moment I am I want to leave this place. Because you are right, Senator Boswellâembittered people have no role to play here.

But we do have a role in scrutiny. Some of us are allocated that role. Others create policy. Others do a whole range of things. But some of us are allocated the role of scrutiny, which is totally appropriate to this parliament, because from that scrutiny and from that adversarial system better government comes. I am not on the front bench for one reason: I do not want to be a minister again. The only people that should sit on an opposition front bench are those that want to be ministers. We have many people on our side of politics that would like to be a minister again. Frankly, I enjoyed being a minister. I enjoyed the nine years. I enjoyed the eight years in cabinet. I probably enjoyed spending $60 billion in six years as defence minister. But for me that was enough. I do not actually aspire to do it again. I am also a believer that, having been elected by the people of Victoria, I should serve my term unless health or something else intervenes. I do not ask for a job outside politics. I live off my backbench salary and I am quite satisfied to do so. You do not have to actually serve on the front benchâas you would probably realise, not having been a ministerâto actually fulfil a role in politics. One of those roles must be scrutiny.

What I have said about this expense issue is two separate issues. You did not mention one of them but I am going to mention it again tonight. I will get to that in a moment. The other issue is: what is legitimate expenditure for a department to pick up the entertainment costs of a minister? I spelt out the criteria yesterday. Official functions are fine. There are plenty of those. Tim Fischer put a whole range of those before us yesterday although he did not fully answer the question. There was a second, grey area which you mentionedâACTU officials, business people, all those sorts of ones. I think they are grey areas. It is something I never did. I never stuck the taxpayer with that. But I can understand they may fall within guidelines. But I say here again that the guidelines do not cover personal staff, departmental officers and journalists. So, if people transgress on your side or have transgressed on our side, we should say they are transgressors. I said last night they were not rorters but I said they were outside the guidelines. If people on our side of politics were outside the guidelines, then they can take the scrutiny.

But why did you not raise that at the time and see if they were outside the guidelines? We are now checking this government and I say those people and those occasions are outside the guidelines. Have you seen any minister come in and table the guidelines, Senator Boswell? Of course they have not. Why not? The ministerial guidelines is a secret document, apparently. It is not publicly available. But I went back to the old one. I assume they have not changed much. I read the guidelines. It simply does not fit into these guidelines. We were given $10,000 as ministers, eventually rolled into salary because of the substantiation rules, to fit these very circumstances. It is already in their salary package for those specific circumstances when you want to take a journalist, staff member, visiting businessmen or trade union officials out. You do not need to send the bill back to the department in those circumstances.

But the real problem in this was not really that. The real problem is that the question asked for the names of the individuals that were the beneficiaries of the taxpayers' funds. The taxpayers are entitled to know that. But what happens? The first time the question is asked, by Senator O'Brien, all the names are given. When I put questions on notice about five ministers the replies are deliberately delayed. They go over to the minister's office and they are rejected. Then the chiefs of staffâand you can make inquiries: they are your peopleâget together and say, `We've got to put a stop to this. We'll eliminate the names on that list and we'll put in broad generic descriptions,' not even giving the numbers in some cases. Where is the justification for that? If I had FOIed them it would, firstly, have cost the government an absolute fortune to answer the questions and, secondly, they would have had to give me the names of the individuals. Because it is illegal if those very chiefs of staff try to direct the FOI officer in the department as to those particular matters.

Then the senator says: `Why the NATs? They don't have any track record.' I don't want to go over the old ground too much. I still say that the greatest act of thievery I have ever seen in this parliament by anyone was a National Party minister and shadow minister claiming $68,000 travel allowance in Melbourne, where he lived for heaven's sakeâtax free! I have never claimed a cent in Melbourne tax free, but $68,000 worth!

talk.start.para: âYour Prime Minister was doing it out here.

âYou are saying our Prime Minister was doing it? When? As Prime Minister? The answer is no, he didn't do it as Prime Minister at all. One of the key points of Senator Boswell's speechâand I have to agree with him on somethingâwas that the department determines whether the payments are okay or not. I agree. That helps the ministers out a bit. It gives them a bit of clearance that these payments were ticked off by the department. That does give them a fair bit of clearance on both sides of politics. But those departmental secretaries should not have done that. I can just imagine what my old mandarin Tony Ayres would have said if I had sent him over a bill for $140 because I had taken someone out to the Ottoman. Being a Brunswick born boy, he would have got that bill, he would have brought it over to the office, he would have inserted it in an orifice and said: `That's what you can do with that bill, Minister.' So there is a weakness here, but not only on the ministerial side; there is also a weakness on the administrative side. Those bills should not have been ticked.

speech.para: But what does Senator Boswell say to the Sharp claim for $1,790 for his own home entertainment? Does he really think that is a proper use of taxpayers' money? It is not for industry representatives. It is for businessmen. Aren't these just the locals whom Sharp has decided to put on a meal for? What do you say about him at the Cowra function, which clearly is a veterans' function, yet the Department of Transport gets stuck with the bill? What do you say about that Southern Highlands function that is in there, which is clearly nothing to do with the Transport portfolio, yet that department got stuck with the entertainment expenses? I have said it before and I will say it again: this is not a rort, and I have never claimed it to be a rort. What I have claimed it to be is an infringement of the guidelines in which departmental secretaries are complicitous in as much as they have ticked the bills on both sides of politics.

But the real tragedy of this, the real thing that brought this to a head, is that I found out about the conspiracy because before I got the answers. I found out about the chiefs-of-staff meeting. I was told: `When you get those answers, you will no longer see the names of the individuals. All you will get to see is their broad description.' And sure enough, yesterday and today as the five sets of answers floated in, that is exactly what we got. As always in these things, the greater crime is not in the commission of what occurred but in the cover-up. Senator Boswell has a responsibility as Leader of the National Party to explain why that cover-up occurred, why your senior staffers were a part of it and whether any of your ministers knew about it. You might get on your feet another time and answer those questions.

talk.start.para: âAs the Chair of the Senate Legislation Committee on the Environment, Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, I would like to make some remarks about Arthur Boyd. Arthur Boyd was a great Australian and a great Australian artist. His death last Sunday takes from us a former Australian of the Year, a leading philanthropist and a world renowned painter, sculptor and designer. Arthur Boyd was born in 1920 at Murrumbeena in Victoria and was a member of one of Australia's greatest artistic families. He left school at age 14 and briefly attended art classes at the National Gallery School in Melbourne. However, as he commented later in life, what he observed on the way to and from his art classes was of more use to him as an artist than the classes were themselves. Surroundings were an important influence throughout the life of Arthur Boyd. In 1936 he went to live with his grandfather at Rosebud in the Mornington Peninsula and completed works for his first exhibition. The Mornington Peninsula landscapes were reflected in these paintings exhibited in Melbourne in 1937.

speech.para: Arthur Boyd served in the Australian Army during the Second World War and his work of this period reflects his experience of the war. In an enterprising adventure after the war, Arthur ran a pottery at Murrumbeena in conjunction with his brother-in-law, John Perceval. But in 1949 Arthur Boyd became a full-time painter and continued his theme of landscapes while also diversifying to murals on religious themes in the house of his uncle, Martin Boyd, near Berwick in Victoria.

His public commissions commenced with a ceramic sculpture for the 1956 Olympic Swimming Pool in Melbourne and the more famous Great Hall Tapestry in this building, which was woven by the Victorian Weavers Trust and based on a 1984 landscape painting by Arthur Boyd, which today is on exhibition near the post office on the first floor of the parliament building. In 1958 Boyd's work, along with that of another great Australian artist, Arthur Streeton, was chosen to represent Australia at the Venice Biennale.

As I have mentioned, surroundings were an important influence on the work of Arthur Boyd. From Port Phillip Bay, the Mornington Peninsula, Central Australia, London, Italy, Tuscany and the Shoalhaven region of the south coast of New South Wales, surroundings and life experiences influenced both the mediums and the styles in which Boyd painted. Landscape remains Boyd's most recognisable style, but during the later years of his life Boyd's work became more figurative in style and diverse in medium. His art diversified as far as graphics and as a designer for the ballet and theatre sets of the Australian Ballet and various theatre companies.

One of Boyd's most famous series of paintings was entitled The Half-caste Bride, which was based on a visit he made to Central Australia in 1958. It has been said that this trip was a turning point in Boyd's life with the artist thereafter concentrating on more figurative works rather than the landscapes which he had done prior to this. Writing in the Sun-Herald today, Jeffrey Makin describes Boyd's work as a narrative. He said:
Boyd was an intuitive painter. His painting was always sensual, tactile, which can be traced back to his beginnings at Murrumbeena in his father's pottery studio.

In the late 1950s, Boyd and his wife, Yvonne Lenney, and family moved to England. In 1960, Boyd had his first exhibition in London, and Boyd and his family moved between London, Australia and Italy from the 1960s. He did not return to Australia until the 1970s, when he took up a fellowship in creative art at the Australian National University.

Boyd's list of public accolades do not come much better. He was Australian of the Year in 1995 and Irish Australian of the Year in 1988. He was awarded an OBE in 1970, an AO in 1979 and promoted to AC in 1992. He was Australia Post's first living legend to appear on postage stamps in 1999. As well as being a prominent artist, as I said, Boyd was a great philanthropist. I will list some of the bodies which benefited from his generosity. The National Gallery of Australia has been a recipient of many thousands of pieces from Boyd's personal collection. In another act of great kindness and foresight, in 1993 the Boyd family donated their property in the Shoalhaven, `Bundanon', to the people of Australia. And this estate now provides an artist in residence program, it houses an educational centre and a theatre, and a concert hall is being built. In conclusion, I would like to again quote Jeffrey Makin who, writing in the Herald Sun on 28 April, said:

The Boyd legend is indelibly a Melbourne success story. Together with Sydney Nolan, he took the Australian landscape to London and almost single handedly created an international market for Australian art where there wasn't one.

So, on behalf of the Senate Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee, I would like to offer condolences to the Boyd family, and commend Arthur Boyd for his kind, philanthropic nature and for his enormous contribution to the development of Australian art both domestically and internationally.

talk.start.para: âI rise in the adjournment debate to speak about my recent visit as shadow minister for veterans' affairs on behalf of the opposition, the parliament of Australia and the people of Australia to Gallipoli and other places where Australian soldiers, airmen and naval personnel have served in wars of this century.

speech.para: As part of my study tour, I visited and had talks with overseas representatives dealing with veterans' issues in Greece, Egypt, Great Britain and Turkey. I also visited Macedonia to look at the terrible refugee situation there, and tomorrow I hope to have an opportunity to speak about that experience. In each of those placesâAthens, El Alamein and Battersea Parkâwhere there are memorials to Australian service men and women who died in the world wars of this century I had the opportunity to lay a wreath on behalf of the parliament and the people of Australia. In each of those Commonwealth war graves cemeteries there are, unfortunately, large numbers of Australians buried.

I want to congratulate the Commonwealth War Graves Commission for the excellent way they maintain those graves, very often in difficult conditions. At El Alamein you could not see a more hostile desert environment, including those that we are used to in outback Australia. It is very well maintained and it is very moving to be there and see the many hundreds of Australian graves. The graves were mainly those of our soldiers who were killed at the famous battle of El Alamein that was a turning point in the Second World War. In Athens there is a Commonwealth war graves cemeteryânow surrounded by suburban Athensâwhere several hundred Australians who were killed defending Greece and Crete in 1941 are buried. I attended those war graves and laid a wreath, accompanied by the head of the Greek veterans' affairs organisation. At Battersea Park there is a simple memorial to the 5,500 young Australian aircrew from Bomber Command who died in the Second World War, and again I was able to lay a wreath.

As far as the veterans' affairs part of my study tour overseas was concerned, the highlight was being able to be at Gallipoli last weekend on the 84th anniversary of the landing of the original Anzacs at Anzac Cove on 25 April 1915. One cannot go there but be moved by being at the original place which is so redolent of Australian history. The places that I had heard of and read about in the history booksânot only Anzac Cove but Lone Pine, Courtney's Post, Quinn's Post and The Nekâare all there in such a close area. To see the area where those original Anzacs fought and died in such large numbers in such a small area is quite overwhelming. Again, the war graves and the memorials to our soldiers who were killed fighting there are very well kept and are very moving in themselves.

I also want to say that the ceremony itself was moving in that the speeches of the Governor-General, Sir William Dean, both at the dawn service at Anzac Cove and at Lone Pine at midday, were, I think, two of the best speeches I have heard commemorating the dead who served our country. I draw the attention of all Australians to Sir William's words, which I think are very much his own words, written and expressed by himself. They are a great peroration in honour of not only the soldiers who died there but also what it means to Australia.

To be at Anzac Cove as the dawn broke at 5.30 in the morning was most moving. As the hills gradually emerged behind, I realised what an extraordinary task it was for those Australian soldiers to come ashore and be faced with those very steep cliffs and gullies in that dawn light. Then, as the dawn came up, I was moved by the sight of 5,000 or 6,000 people cramped on that Anzac Cove site. The most moving thing of all was that 80 per cent of the people there were under the age of 30. Many of them had slept the night amongst the graves of the Australian soldiers buried on Anzac Cove. They wanted to make sure they were there for the dawn service. Apparently in recent times one Turkish commentator said, `Isn't it a wonderful thing that these young Australians have come back so many generations later and have laid down and slept amongst the graves of their forebears who fought here?' The Turkish people saw that as a tribute, even though there is concern about the damage it may do to the cemetery.

Again, at Lone Pine there must have been 6,000 or 7,000 people at the service. You could see they were Australians because they were dressed very informally in T-shirts and jeans, wearing sunglasses and hats, but all were greatly moved by the ceremony and treated it with great respect. I had the opportunity to talk with many of them and walk with them up the road past Johnston's Jolly, Quinn's Post, Courtney's Post, The Nek, up to Chunuk Bair for the New Zealand service. All of them had made an absolute effort to come once in their life to Anzac Cove and Gallipoli to be there because that was part of being an Australian.

I made some notes on the plane coming back. These were the sorts of things these young Australians said about the reasons they were there: `It is a pilgrimage which you have to make.' `This is where Australia as a nation really began.' `I just had to come to this place which is so important to Australia.' `You cannot be an Australian unless you visit and see for yourself what these soldiers did here.' `I cannot explain why, but I know that I just had to come here once in my life.' `My great-grandfather served in World War I. I owed it to him and his family to be here.' `It is overwhelming to see where so many ordinary Australians fought and died.' Those were the remarks made by these young Australians. To me and to all of us, we know that the commemoration of the Anzac spirit clearly is not going to die when so many young Australians are willing to make that effort to be there and to understand what makes it so important to them as an Australian.

The reason I went on my own personal pilgrimage or odyssey is that on the morning of 25 April 1915 my grandfather, Karl Timcke, from the 10th battalion in South Australia, landed on the beach at Gallipoli. He lasted about a day before he was severely wounded. He lay for two days in no-man's-land before he was found and brought home on the first hospital ship with a very severe head wound. He was demobilised from the Army, and in 1916-17 he was a founding member of the Returned Services League in South Australia and served on the committee. Unfortunately, his wounds meant that he became ill and he died in 1924, leaving behind a young family, one of whom was my mother.

I am the first member of the family to return to Gallipoli to see where my grandfather was badly wounded. I have to say that it was a very moving experience personally; very emotional. I hope that from now on every succeeding generation of my family takes the opportunity to go to Gallipoli to see where their forebear, my grandfather, served and bled, and to realise that the blood from which they are descended has been spilt on that sacred soil at Gallipoli. I hope all the succeeding generations of my descendants get that opportunity.

My mother is in her 79th year. When I return home on Friday I will be able to take back to her some stones that I gathered from the very beach on which her father, my grandfather, landed as a small memento of what Anzac Cove and Gallipoli mean to my family but, above all else, to all Australians.
